description: Mac Integration Basics is an excellent starting point for people working with Macintosh systems in a networked environment. The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. Viewers who pass the Mac Integration Basics exam will be awarded the Apple Certified Associate certification.
name: Mac Integration Basics 10.11
subtitle: El Capitan 10.11

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Don give a general overview of what you can expect in the upcoming episodes. They cover what the show's about, the target audience, what will be covered overall, and other topics.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.098 --> 00:00:04.626
[SOUND]

2

[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.524 --> 00:00:12.888
In this segment, we're gonna give
you an overview of the upcoming

4
00:00:12.888 --> 00:00:16.553
Mac Integration Basic series that we
have coming up here on ITProTV, and

5
00:00:16.553 --> 00:00:17.810

6

gonna ask you maybe give you some answers

7
00:00:21.517 --> 00:00:23.747
here about this upcoming and

8
00:00:23.747 --> 00:00:27.361
[LAUGH] The first one is, generally, what

00:00:27.361 --> 00:00:31.190
to Mac Integration Basics, what does

10

is one of the two exams that you can take

ACA certification,
you only gotta pass one of them.

13
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:39.260
You get to pick.

This is just one of those two.

15

Now, Mac Management Basics focuses

17
00:00:47.870 --> 00:00:50.690
Versus this one, Mac Integration Basics,
which actually focuses more

18
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:53.640

well with Windows machines.

19
00:00:53.640 --> 00:00:54.740
I know what you're saying.

20

What do I care about Windows, right?

21
00:00:55.870 --> 00:00:59.550
But in the business world,
you're gonna find where most environments

22
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:03.240
are not 100% Mac, or
even 100% Windows anymore.

23
00:01:03.240 --> 00:01:06.650
Now you oftentimes have environments
where you've got a mixture of the two.

24
00:01:06.650 --> 00:01:10.120
And getting them to play nice is kind
of an important step that we have to go

25
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:11.590
through to get these things communicating.

26
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:15.630
So what we find is that,
if you work for a company,

27
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:20.150
if you're an IT administrator and
you're tasked with supporting Macs on your

28
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.590
network, you need to have a knowledge
of some of those functions,

29
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.160
how these things work and Mac
Integration Basics is what covers that.

30
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:29.920
>> Yeah, Don, you actually started
hinting at my next questions,

31
00:01:29.920 --> 00:01:32.870
which is, who is this series intended for?

32
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:36.070
>> Yeah, it's really going to be
those IT administrators right?

33
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:39.730
So, if you're a home user and you've got
a couple of Mac's, this is not for you.

34
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:43.897
If you've got a, let's say you work for
a company that's 100% Mac based, well,

35
00:01:43.897 --> 00:01:45.210
again, this one's not for

36
00:01:45.210 --> 00:01:49.080
you cause we're gonna show you how
to integrate systems you don't have.

37
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:52.150
So for you to jump over to Mac Management
Basics, that's a better one for you, cause

38
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:56.110
you learn all the different ways to manage
your Macs and there's really cool stuff.

39
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:58.620
But if you've got that mix,
if you're an IT administrator and

40
00:01:58.620 --> 00:02:01.130
you're responsible for Windows and
Mac, this is the show for

41
00:02:01.130 --> 00:02:03.040
you cause we show how to
mix those two together.

42
00:02:03.040 --> 00:02:05.600
>> All right, now that we know
what the show's gonna be about,

43
00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:07.625
generally, and who it's for.

44
00:02:07.625 --> 00:02:11.900
Wet our appetites just a bit and
give us some topic details,

45
00:02:11.900 --> 00:02:14.040
some of the things that we're
gonna see in the series.

46
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:14.651

47

that we'll be using to guide the show.

48
00:02:17.860 --> 00:02:19.292
Let me just bring this
up here on the screen.

49

And basically we're gonna start off
talking about network accounts, right?

50

Where are user accounts exist because
you've got like active directory,

51

an open directory, and all that stuff.

52
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:27.285
So we're kind of start off with those.

53
00:02:27.285 --> 00:02:29.000
We'll talking about file sharing and

54

how to get files to transfer over
the network between Windows and Macs.

55
00:02:32.400 --> 00:02:35.320
And then we'll take a look at email,
calendars, and contacts so

56
00:02:35.320 --> 00:02:37.130
I like to call it collaboration software.

57
00:02:37.130 --> 00:02:40.920
Ways that we can communicate where
your clients might be Macs but

58

59
00:02:44.230 --> 00:02:46.010
We'll also take a look at security.

60

There are a ton of security
features inside of Mac OS and

61

they all help protect you.

62
00:02:51.530 --> 00:02:53.900
But some of them get in the way
of you communicating with other

63
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:54.600
machines on the network.

64
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:56.710
So we've gotta understand what
each of those systems do and

65

that configured properly.

66
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:00.410
Then we take a look at printing.

67
00:03:00.410 --> 00:03:02.870
Printing is less important
these days than it used to be.

68
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:05.050

many environments still have printers.

69
00:03:05.050 --> 00:03:08.460

to those and manage that system.

70
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:10.830
And then,
we take a look at instant messaging.

71
00:03:10.830 --> 00:03:11.540
Right?

72
00:03:11.540 --> 00:03:14.680
This is the messenger
app inside of Mac OS.

73
00:03:14.680 --> 00:03:17.560
A lot of people use it with iTunes and
iCloud.

74
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:21.050
But, you can actually use
it non Mac chat servers.

75
00:03:21.050 --> 00:03:23.510
So, we'll see a chance to work with that.

76
00:03:23.510 --> 00:03:26.390
Lastly, we get to see
what's really important.

77
00:03:26.390 --> 00:03:27.710
Data management and back up.

78
00:03:27.710 --> 00:03:29.120
Right?
Protecting our data and

79
00:03:29.120 --> 00:03:30.300
being able to restore it.

80
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:32.910
And cross platform compatibility.

81
00:03:32.910 --> 00:03:37.720
It might not be that I have a Mac and
a Windows machine, it might be that I have

82
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:41.788
one machine that I need to do both,
run Mac and Windows applications.

83
00:03:41.788 --> 00:03:43.990
So, we talk about a few
different ways to do that and

84
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:48.270
some really neat infrastructure that helps
you transition from one over to the other.

85
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:48.790
>> All right, Don.

86
00:03:48.790 --> 00:03:50.640
So now that we have some
more of the detail.

87
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:54.170
We have some more of the basic
overview of what we're looking at,

88
00:03:54.170 --> 00:03:57.060
you did mention an exam, and
I'm guessing that most of the good

89
00:03:57.060 --> 00:04:00.170
people that are gonna be watching this
are gonna want to take that exam.

90
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:01.340
Give us some of the details on that.

91
00:04:01.340 --> 00:04:03.940
What can I do?
I want to get signed up and take it.

92
00:04:03.940 --> 00:04:04.680
What do I got to do?

93
00:04:04.680 --> 00:04:05.910
>> This is one of the nice ones.

94
00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:07.480
If you want to get your ACA,

95
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:09.780
you don't have to go to some
special testing center somewhere.

96
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:10.940
You don't have to go to Apple.

97

the comfort of your own home.

98
00:04:12.960 --> 00:04:16.750
You could just go right over to Apple's
website and sign up for the exam and

99
00:04:16.750 --> 00:04:18.440
take it tonight, if you want.

100
00:04:18.440 --> 00:04:19.210
It's really nice.

101
00:04:19.210 --> 00:04:20.400
And it's pretty inexpensive too.

102
00:04:20.400 --> 00:04:23.260
It's $65, which is a lot
less than a lot of the other

103
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:24.730
certification exams that are out there.

104
00:04:24.730 --> 00:04:27.960
I've got the details kind of
pulled up here from their website.

105
00:04:27.960 --> 00:04:33.249
If you go to
training.apple.com/itpro/macinteg,

106
00:04:33.249 --> 00:04:36.670
i-n-t-e-g, /1011 exam.

107
00:04:36.670 --> 00:04:38.210
Right, that's that URL right.

108
00:04:38.210 --> 00:04:38.880
Let me zoom in on that.

109
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:39.750
There we go.

110
00:04:39.750 --> 00:04:42.070
So you see that URL, but
if you go to that webpage,

111
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:46.500
they have all the exam information right
there and so you'll see it's $65, you get

112
00:04:46.500 --> 00:04:50.790
two hours to take it, and you can take it
right from the comfort of your own home.

113
00:04:50.790 --> 00:04:54.461
They’ve got the link right
here training.apple.com/acrs.

114
00:04:54.461 --> 00:04:58.490
You can take the exam, as soon as you’re
done you will immediately get a pass or

115
00:04:58.490 --> 00:05:01.460
a fail score so you will know that
you’ve passed, you’re certified.

116
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:02.500
And you're ready to rock.

117
00:05:02.500 --> 00:05:03.530
It's all right there.

118
00:05:03.530 --> 00:05:06.260
All in all one of the better testing
experiences that are out there.

119
00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:07.430
All right, that's basically it.

120
00:05:07.430 --> 00:05:11.980
That is the Mac Integration Basics ACE
in a nutshell and it's a lot of fun.

121
00:05:11.980 --> 00:05:15.220
It's definitely a good time, if you
are that person responsible for Macs and

122
00:05:15.220 --> 00:05:16.830
Windows, this is the place to be.

123
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:18.610
So that sounds exciting.

124
00:05:18.610 --> 00:05:19.140
Stay tuned.

125
00:05:19.140 --> 00:05:20.450
These episodes are coming up.

126
00:05:20.450 --> 00:05:24.120
If it doesn't sound too terribly exciting,
if you just work in the Mac only world,

127
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:26.230
then jump over and
check out our Mac Management Basics.

128
00:05:26.230 --> 00:05:27.170
It's already filmed.

129
00:05:27.170 --> 00:05:28.520
It's already in our course library.

130
00:05:28.520 --> 00:05:29.680
You can certainly watch that.

131
00:05:29.680 --> 00:05:31.540
And if you wanna learn more
about Windows or Linux,

132
00:05:31.540 --> 00:05:34.190
we've got plenty of other courses
on that in our library too.

133
00:05:34.190 --> 00:05:37.592
But for those of you that are sticking
with me from Mac Integration Basics,

134
00:05:37.592 --> 00:05:39.001
well, enough me rambling on.

135
00:05:39.001 --> 00:05:41.393
Let's get this show started.

136
00:05:41.393 --> 00:05:47.834
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain and demonstrate how to connect Mac computers to Directory Services. They start by explaining the concept of Directory Services. Then they show you how to create an OpenDirectory Server and connect a Mac client. Finally, they show you how to connect a Mac client to a Windows Active Directory Domain server.
episodes.title: Directory Servers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.148 --> 00:00:17.480
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:19.570
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:23.450
we are moving forward with our
brand new Mac integration series,

5
00:00:23.450 --> 00:00:26.130
Mac integration basic series,
should I say, to get that right.

6
00:00:26.130 --> 00:00:29.860
Joining us in the studio today is our good
friend and mentor in that very endeavor,

7
00:00:29.860 --> 00:00:31.170
is our friend Don Bizet.

8
00:00:31.170 --> 00:00:32.400
Don, welcome to the show, sir.

9
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:33.520
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel,

10
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:36.400
and just ready to jump into
another exciting Mac series.

11
00:00:36.400 --> 00:00:39.360
We're gonna kick this one off big
style and not mess around with

12
00:00:39.360 --> 00:00:43.350
the simple outlines or anything like that
and dive right into directory servers.

13
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:45.740
Now this is pretty cool because I know

14
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:48.130
many of you guys watch
the Mac Management Basic series.

15
00:00:48.130 --> 00:00:50.270
We've covered Apple's Open Directory,

16
00:00:50.270 --> 00:00:54.880
which is a great way to have centralized
user accounts in an all Apple environment.

17
00:00:54.880 --> 00:00:56.830
But if you're dealing
with Windows servers,

18
00:00:56.830 --> 00:01:00.430
you might have a different directory
server, like Microsoft's Active Directory.

19
00:01:00.430 --> 00:01:04.090
And in this episode, we're gonna take
a look at how we can get our Mac clients

20
00:01:04.090 --> 00:01:07.420
to be all friendly and cozy up nice
to Microsoft's Active Directory.

21
00:01:07.420 --> 00:01:10.760
Now before I dive into those, let's start
with something a little bit more basic,

22
00:01:10.760 --> 00:01:12.530
cuz this is the basic show.

23
00:01:12.530 --> 00:01:14.200
What the heck is a directory server,
right?

24
00:01:14.200 --> 00:01:15.030
Maybe you don't know.

25
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:18.660
Maybe you haven't seen the Mac Management
Basics series, and that's perfectly fine.

26
00:01:18.660 --> 00:01:24.050
So, a directory server is a centralized
database of user accounts.

27
00:01:24.050 --> 00:01:26.290
Now, normally on a Mac,
when you create a user account,

28
00:01:26.290 --> 00:01:28.730
it's created right there
on that individual Mac.

29
00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:31.890
So, Daniel's got a Macbook right here,
I've got a Macbook.

30
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:36.060
If I create a user account on my Mac,
I can't go to Daniel's laptop and

31
00:01:36.060 --> 00:01:37.010
log in as me.

32
00:01:37.010 --> 00:01:38.530
The account doesn't exist there.

33
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:41.102
The account exists only on my laptop.

34
00:01:41.102 --> 00:01:42.780
And you guys have probably
worked with these before.

35
00:01:42.780 --> 00:01:43.890
Let me just show you real quick here.

36
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:44.900
I'll take this one.

37
00:01:44.900 --> 00:01:47.740
So here's an El Capitan install.

38
00:01:47.740 --> 00:01:49.080
It's pretty much stock.

39
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:52.340
And I'm gonna go up here
into my System Preferences.

40
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:55.680
And into the Users and Groups system
preference whenever it comes up.

41
00:01:55.680 --> 00:01:57.400
There it is, Users and Groups.

42
00:01:57.400 --> 00:02:00.900
And when I go in here,
we're gonna see local users, right?

43
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:04.850
I've got my user that I created
when I installed El Capitan, right?

44
00:02:04.850 --> 00:02:08.430
It asked me to pick a user name, so there
I am, Don Pezet, and it made me an admin.

45
00:02:08.430 --> 00:02:09.610
And then there's a guest account.

46
00:02:09.610 --> 00:02:12.940
And the guest account's turned off
unless you turn on find my Mac.

47
00:02:12.940 --> 00:02:15.010
That'll enable it.

48
00:02:15.010 --> 00:02:17.540
But in this case,
I just have the one user account.

49
00:02:17.540 --> 00:02:21.780
And if I start adding more user accounts,
they're just added right here on this Mac.

50
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:24.150
Now, for a home user, that's fine.

51
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:26.160
If you're a home user,
if this is your Mac, and

52
00:02:26.160 --> 00:02:27.600
you're the only one that uses it,
who cares?

53
00:02:27.600 --> 00:02:29.850
You just have the one account and
that's it.

54
00:02:29.850 --> 00:02:33.660
But if you work in a business or
a school and you've got hundreds or

55
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:38.228
even thousands of Macs, I want to be able
to sit at one computer and log in as me,

56
00:02:38.228 --> 00:02:41.926
and then get up and go to another
computer and still log in as me.

57
00:02:41.926 --> 00:02:44.297
And I don't want to have to create
a user account on every single

58
00:02:44.297 --> 00:02:45.710
machine to do that.

59
00:02:45.710 --> 00:02:48.060
It's even more important
when it comes to changes.

60
00:02:48.060 --> 00:02:49.830
What if I need to reset my password?

61
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:52.890
Well, I don't wanna go to 1,000
computers and change my password.

62
00:02:54.050 --> 00:02:56.150
I wanna do it in one place and
be done with it.

63
00:02:56.150 --> 00:02:57.750
Or what if we terminate an employee?

64
00:02:57.750 --> 00:03:00.177
Like, Daniel over here has been coasting
on the edge for quite some time.

65
00:03:00.177 --> 00:03:03.140
If we decide to cut him loose,
I need to disable his account.

66
00:03:03.140 --> 00:03:05.130
And I don't wanna have to go
to 1,000 computers to do it,

67
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:06.870
that's way too much time for
him to wreak some havoc.

68
00:03:06.870 --> 00:03:11.020
I wanna have a central place that
I go to to manage those accounts.

69
00:03:11.020 --> 00:03:12.965
And that's what a directory does for us.

70
00:03:12.965 --> 00:03:17.480
It gives us that central user database
where all the user accounts exist not on

71
00:03:17.480 --> 00:03:21.540
an individual machine but
in a centralized server.

72
00:03:21.540 --> 00:03:24.250
Now Apple has a product that does that.

73
00:03:24.250 --> 00:03:27.440
So here I am on another Mac
that's running the server app,

74
00:03:27.440 --> 00:03:29.667
so this is my OSX-SERVER01 machine.

75
00:03:29.667 --> 00:03:31.610
It's running the server app.

76
00:03:31.610 --> 00:03:34.680
And in the server app if you
dig down under Advanced,

77
00:03:34.680 --> 00:03:37.250
you'll see where there's
the Open Directory, right?

78
00:03:37.250 --> 00:03:41.910
That's Apple's own directory service,
and it's based on OpenLDAP.

79
00:03:41.910 --> 00:03:45.550
LDAP is
the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol.

80
00:03:45.550 --> 00:03:49.058
It's an open standard, there's a ton
of people out there that support it.

81
00:03:49.058 --> 00:03:53.670
And it is just a central repository for
user accounts and groups, right?

82
00:03:53.670 --> 00:03:55.850
We can group the users together.

83
00:03:55.850 --> 00:03:58.440
Apple took OpenLDAP and

84
00:03:58.440 --> 00:04:01.710
modified it a little bit to create
their Open Directory Server.

85
00:04:01.710 --> 00:04:05.730
And so if I want a quick and
easy directory server, I can whip this up.

86
00:04:05.730 --> 00:04:08.750
It's pretty easy to start it here,
I'll run through it real quick.

87
00:04:08.750 --> 00:04:12.450
If I choose Open Directory and just hit

let me tell you.

546
00:25:22.460 --> 00:25:25.330
You guys don't see him on camera, but
really he's just a pain to be around.

547
00:25:25.330 --> 00:25:28.680
So, I decide to fire him and
he's gonna do bad stuff on the network.

548
00:25:28.680 --> 00:25:31.390
So, I come in here and
I just disable his account, right?

549
00:25:31.390 --> 00:25:34.050
So, I'm gonna come in here and
disable that account.

550
00:25:34.050 --> 00:25:36.060
And now, he's disabled.

551
00:25:36.060 --> 00:25:38.570
He's not allowed to log in on the network,
right?

552
00:25:38.570 --> 00:25:39.790
I've kicked him out.

553
00:25:39.790 --> 00:25:43.820
And if I jump back over here,
well he's still logged in here right, but

554
00:25:43.820 --> 00:25:44.702
if he logs out.

555
00:25:44.702 --> 00:25:46.117
Log him out.

556
00:25:46.117 --> 00:25:48.974
And I've got the security to chase
him out of the office, so he's out,

557
00:25:48.974 --> 00:25:51.783
and he just sneaks right back in
through the break room or something and

558
00:25:51.783 --> 00:25:55.780
goes to somebody else's machine, he sits
down and says I'm going to log in, right?

559
00:25:55.780 --> 00:26:02.730
Well, he comes in to log in and
let's get this punched in.

560
00:26:02.730 --> 00:26:06.070
And the computer takes
his account information,

561
00:26:06.070 --> 00:26:10.460
sends it over to the Active Directory and
he's not allowed to log in.

562
00:26:10.460 --> 00:26:12.030
His account's been disabled.

563
00:26:12.030 --> 00:26:13.470
Right?
He can't get in.

564
00:26:13.470 --> 00:26:14.730
The system's now secure.

565
00:26:14.730 --> 00:26:16.030
Right?
That's what centralized

566
00:26:16.030 --> 00:26:16.950
management gets us.

567
00:26:16.950 --> 00:26:19.110
If I have 1000 Macs.

568
00:26:19.110 --> 00:26:23.100
I disable him in one place and now he
can't log into any of those thousand max.

569
00:26:23.100 --> 00:26:26.310
Right that’s the importance of
a Central Directory Service and

570
00:26:26.310 --> 00:26:28.100
it really does provide
the great functionality.

571
00:26:28.100 --> 00:26:32.230
And if you got bought Windows and Mac.

572
00:26:32.230 --> 00:26:36.050
Using the Windows active directory really
is gonna give you that one central place.

573
00:26:36.050 --> 00:26:39.096
Windows machine can't
authenticate open directory yet

574
00:26:39.096 --> 00:26:42.020
Macs can authenticate
against the active directory.

575
00:26:42.020 --> 00:26:45.270
So when you've got both, you normally
are gonna choose the active directory.

576
00:26:45.270 --> 00:26:47.540
You're not gonna choose open
directory in that scenario.

577
00:26:47.540 --> 00:26:48.250
>> Yeah.
And

578
00:26:48.250 --> 00:26:52.200
Windows active directory is
probably the soup du jour, right?

579
00:26:52.200 --> 00:26:55.050
It's most likely what you're gonna
be dealing with when it comes to

580
00:26:55.050 --> 00:26:55.890
a directory structure.

581
00:26:55.890 --> 00:26:57.980
Not that you can't see the other,
but by and

582
00:26:57.980 --> 00:27:02.940
large Windows active directory is taking
a large bite out of the market share.

583
00:27:02.940 --> 00:27:04.560
So I actually would have dealt with this.

584
00:27:04.560 --> 00:27:07.450
I've worked in large active
directory environments and

585
00:27:07.450 --> 00:27:10.630
we had some people go you know what,
I'm a Mac user.

586
00:27:10.630 --> 00:27:12.260
Maybe some graphics people,

587
00:27:12.260 --> 00:27:15.800
printing people, they enjoy their
Mac's cuz they do a great job at that.

588
00:27:15.800 --> 00:27:18.670
And I would have been lost and
it shows you how far they've come.

589
00:27:18.670 --> 00:27:20.870
Very easy to integrate this.

590
00:27:20.870 --> 00:27:22.250
Into the active directory environment.

591
00:27:22.250 --> 00:27:23.850
That was not difficult at all though.

592
00:27:23.850 --> 00:27:26.900
>> No it isn't assuming you know
the quirks of active director.

593
00:27:26.900 --> 00:27:28.560
I had to know to set the DNS server.

594
00:27:28.560 --> 00:27:30.760
I had to know the formats of
the name of the server but

595
00:27:30.760 --> 00:27:33.320
assuming you have that
knowledge it really is easy.

596
00:27:33.320 --> 00:27:34.680
Now they can act and

597
00:27:34.680 --> 00:27:37.550
it's really no different than managing
a Windows machine at that point.

598
00:27:37.550 --> 00:27:40.490
There's no obstacle to bringing
systems into your network.

599
00:27:40.490 --> 00:27:42.280
>> Now we can take that chocolate.

600
00:27:42.280 --> 00:27:43.200
And the peanut butter and

601
00:27:43.200 --> 00:27:46.680
put them together in a tasty
treat which we do enjoy.

602
00:27:46.680 --> 00:27:50.010
Don is there anything else
about working with Macs and

603
00:27:50.010 --> 00:27:52.200
directory services in general.

604
00:27:52.200 --> 00:27:52.840
>> That's about it.

605
00:27:52.840 --> 00:27:55.710
I mean, obviously there's a lot more power
behind all these directory servers, but

606
00:27:55.710 --> 00:27:57.890
the basic functionality is what
we need to know for the exam and

607
00:27:57.890 --> 00:27:59.320
that's what we've seen here.

608
00:27:59.320 --> 00:27:59.900
>> All right Don.

609
00:27:59.900 --> 00:28:03.510
Well thanks for stopping by and
explaining these Mac basics to us.

610
00:28:03.510 --> 00:28:06.930
Integrating our Mac systems inside
of an active directory environment.

611
00:28:06.930 --> 00:28:10.750
Not too difficult, and we need it for the
exam, so it's definitely a good place for

612
00:28:10.750 --> 00:28:11.670
you to get started.

613
00:28:11.670 --> 00:28:13.590
That being said, looks like we've
wrapped up another good show.

614
00:28:13.590 --> 00:28:15.710
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it and
learned something.

615
00:28:15.710 --> 00:28:18.970
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

616
00:28:18.970 --> 00:28:19.660
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

617
00:28:19.660 --> 00:28:21.576
>> And we'll see you next time.

618
00:28:21.576 --> 00:28:26.488

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain file sharing while using a Mac client in a mixed environment. They begin by explaining the two ways in which you will commonly share files; connecting to a network file server and personal file sharing. They describe the different protocols used when connecting a network file share and then demonstrate those connections. Finally, they demonstrate setting up personal file sharing from your Mac.
episodes.title: File Sharing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.050 --> 00:00:16.640
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:16.640 --> 00:00:18.063
I'm your host, Daniel Lowery.

4
00:00:18.063 --> 00:00:21.746
And in today's episode, we are continuing
on with our Mac integration basics class,

5
00:00:21.746 --> 00:00:23.235
that we've been working on.

6
00:00:23.235 --> 00:00:26.690
Joining us back in the studio again today
is none other than our good friend and

7
00:00:26.690 --> 00:00:27.870
mentor, Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.870 --> 00:00:29.110
Don, welcome back to the show, sir.

9
00:00:29.110 --> 00:00:30.050
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel.

10
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:32.520
Ready to jump right back into
the world of Mac integration basics.

11
00:00:32.520 --> 00:00:35.290
And in this episode,
we're gonna take a look at file sharing.

12
00:00:35.290 --> 00:00:39.206
How we can exchange information
between our Mac and other systems.

13
00:00:39.206 --> 00:00:42.422
And we'll talk a little bit about
file sharing between Macs and

14
00:00:42.422 --> 00:00:44.310
other Macs cuz that's kind of cool.

15
00:00:44.310 --> 00:00:46.290
But this is an integration show, right?

16
00:00:46.290 --> 00:00:48.500
So we need to be able to share files and

17
00:00:48.500 --> 00:00:51.382
exchange data with other systems
that aren't necessarily Macs.

18
00:00:51.382 --> 00:00:53.846
So we'll talk about a few other
protocols that are out there for

19
00:00:53.846 --> 00:00:55.487
Unix based systems and Windows systems.

20
00:00:55.487 --> 00:00:58.862
And you'll find that it's actually
pretty easy to exchange files and

21
00:00:58.862 --> 00:00:59.785
get things going.

22
00:00:59.785 --> 00:01:02.860
Now, when we talk about file sharing,
there's two angles we wanna look at it.

23
00:01:02.860 --> 00:01:05.789
We wanna look at it from the side
of a Mac being the client.

24
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:08.820
In other words,
our Mac reaching out on the network and

25
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:10.390
getting files from somebody else.

26
00:01:10.390 --> 00:01:14.340
But we also wanna look at it from
the aspect of our Mac being the server,

27
00:01:14.340 --> 00:01:17.750
the person that's sharing out these
files and giving them to other people.

28
00:01:17.750 --> 00:01:19.970
And you'll find that you've
got a lot of compatibility.

29
00:01:19.970 --> 00:01:23.340
A lot of stuff is built in that
just makes it really easy to do.

30
00:01:23.340 --> 00:01:26.660
And you can be exchanging data on
your network in a short order.

31
00:01:26.660 --> 00:01:30.949
It used to be really challenging
to share files over the network.

32
00:01:30.949 --> 00:01:34.254
I remember some of the first Macs I
worked on that were networked, right?

33
00:01:34.254 --> 00:01:35.998
So a lot of use had Apple IIes and

34
00:01:35.998 --> 00:01:40.220
things like that back in the day
that just weren't on the network.

35
00:01:40.220 --> 00:01:45.010
But I had these SE20s back in the day
that had the old Apple Talk network.

36
00:01:45.010 --> 00:01:48.550
And it was a lot of effort to
get those adaptors hooked up, to

37
00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:51.260
run those little phone cables around, to
get all that stuff hooked up and in place.

38
00:01:51.260 --> 00:01:52.506
Then get everything configured to share.

39
00:01:52.506 --> 00:01:56.758
Today, having a TCP/IP based
network is pretty ubiquitous.

40
00:01:56.758 --> 00:01:57.783
Pretty much everybody has that.

41
00:01:57.783 --> 00:02:00.120
You've got a wireless network or
a wired network.

42
00:02:00.120 --> 00:02:03.240
You plug right in,
you get your IP address.

43
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:06.260
After that, sharing things is
actually really super easy.

44
00:02:06.260 --> 00:02:08.590
But it is important that we run
through all the different options that

45
00:02:08.590 --> 00:02:10.810
are available,
because they do show up on the exam.

46
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:14.680
>> Yeah, I guess that can be a little
confusing to the newcomer of sharing

47
00:02:14.680 --> 00:02:17.580
files, especially inside of Mac,
such as myself.

48
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:19.550
I've only been running a Mac for
about a year, and

49
00:02:19.550 --> 00:02:21.030
I don't do a lot of file sharing.

50
00:02:21.030 --> 00:02:22.800
But there are tons of ways and

51
00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:26.440
protocols that are available
through the TCP/IP protocol itself,

52
00:02:26.440 --> 00:02:29.530
to actually be able to make connections
and share files, right, Don?

53
00:02:29.530 --> 00:02:30.430
>> Yeah, absolutely.

54
00:02:30.430 --> 00:02:33.310
And it's all kinda built
into the Mac already.

55
00:02:33.310 --> 00:02:36.970
Where I say it can be super easy,
let me just show you an example here.

56
00:02:36.970 --> 00:02:41.030
We'll just use straight up Mac sharing and
it's called personal file sharing.

57
00:02:41.030 --> 00:02:42.920
Kinda get a chance to see how that works.

58
00:02:42.920 --> 00:02:44.810
And I'm just gonna take
a folder real quick.

59
00:02:44.810 --> 00:02:47.600
I've got a server here, but actually
I'm not gonna use the server piece.

60
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:49.830
Let me just,
share out a folder real quick.

61
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:51.470
So I'm gonna jump into my
system preferences and

62
00:02:51.470 --> 00:02:52.820
go into the sharing folder.

63
00:02:52.820 --> 00:02:55.690
And I'm just gonna share something
real quick on this system.

64
00:02:55.690 --> 00:02:59.330
And we'll share this software
folder I've got on my desktop.

65
00:02:59.330 --> 00:03:01.220
And I want to make that
available on the network.

66
00:03:01.220 --> 00:03:02.790
So when I add that and

67
00:03:02.790 --> 00:03:06.700
share it out, I'm just kind of giving
access to people and there we go.

68
00:03:06.700 --> 00:03:11.620
Now, for a client, if I'm on a Mac and
I wanna browse and

69
00:03:11.620 --> 00:03:15.590
connect to another Mac's data
on the same network as me,

70
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:18.510
I really don't have to do
a whole lot of crazy stuff.

71
00:03:18.510 --> 00:03:20.012
When you launch your Finder,

72
00:03:20.012 --> 00:03:23.448
in your Finder you're normally
looking at your own stuff, right?

73
00:03:23.448 --> 00:03:27.728
So, I see my favorites, I see my devices
like my Macintosh hard drive, right?

74
00:03:27.728 --> 00:03:28.915
These are the things that I see.

75
00:03:28.915 --> 00:03:31.049
But right beneath it, I've got Shared.

76
00:03:31.049 --> 00:03:36.580
And under Shared, I start to see
computers on my network, right?

77
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:39.600
These are other computers that
are out there on the network and

78
00:03:39.600 --> 00:03:42.060
you'll see I'm connected to
the ITProTV studio network so

79
00:03:42.060 --> 00:03:43.775
I've got all sorts of
stuff showing up in here.

80
00:03:43.775 --> 00:03:47.330
Thomas' laptop, he's in the office
over on the other side of that wall.

81
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:49.410
And a couple other things,
our editing station.

82
00:03:49.410 --> 00:03:52.280
These are all different computers
that are showing up on the network,

83
00:03:52.280 --> 00:03:54.660
including my laptop and other servers.

84
00:03:54.660 --> 00:03:56.980
I can browse and connect to these guys.

85
00:03:56.980 --> 00:04:00.870
And I didn't have to configure anything,
it just found them.

86
00:04:00.870 --> 00:04:03.430
So your Macs,
they run a protocol called Bonjour.

87
00:04:03.430 --> 00:04:07.500
And what Bonjour does it allows one Mac to
discover other Macs on the network, and

88
00:04:07.500 --> 00:04:10.200
it can even discover
non-Macs in some scenarios.

89
00:04:10.200 --> 00:04:14.300
Notice how this OSX-SERVER01 right here,
how it's got a question mark on it?

90
00:04:14.300 --> 00:04:16.600
That probably means that device
is not online right now, or

91
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:18.450
that I'm not seeing it for some reason.

92
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:20.600
I might be on a different network,
or whatever, or

93
00:04:20.600 --> 00:04:22.730
just can't identify what the machine is.

94
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:27.685
But some of these other ones,
like DPLAPTOP-OSX, that's my laptop.

95
00:04:27.685 --> 00:04:30.535
And it shows its little icon cuz it knows
that it's a laptop because it's another

96
00:04:30.535 --> 00:04:34.575
Mac, and it's communicating to it,
and OSX exchanges that information.

97
00:04:34.575 --> 00:04:37.421
And I can browse to one of these
guys to access the files and

98
00:04:37.421 --> 00:04:39.032
information that's on there.

99
00:04:39.032 --> 00:04:43.388
And when I browse to it, the only thing
that it's gonna do is it's gonna ask me to

100
00:04:43.388 --> 00:04:47.700
authenticate, and when I click on it,
so like if I click on OSX-SERVER01.

101
00:04:47.700 --> 00:04:50.280
I can see,
there's Don Pezet's Public Folder and

102
00:04:50.280 --> 00:04:54.200
there's that Software folder I
shared just a moment ago, all right?

103
00:04:54.200 --> 00:04:57.450
Now, sometimes you'll connect to
a system and you won't see anything.

104
00:04:57.450 --> 00:05:03.460
And the reason is this little blurb
right here, connected as guest.

105
00:05:03.460 --> 00:05:05.740
I've connected to that system anonymously.

106
00:05:05.740 --> 00:05:07.760
No user name, no password.

107
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:11.100
And so I'm only seeing things that
are available to basically everybody.

108
00:05:11.100 --> 00:05:13.170
Sometimes you'll connect and
you'll see nothing.

109
00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:15.905
So, for example, if I try and
connect to this editing station.

110
00:05:15.905 --> 00:05:18.470
This is the editing station
here in our studio,

111
00:05:18.470 --> 00:05:21.999
where they store a lot of our videos
as they're being produced and

112
00:05:21.999 --> 00:05:25.093
I've connected to it,
well, no, I haven't, right?

113
00:05:25.093 --> 00:05:26.825
See how it says Not Connected?

114
00:05:26.825 --> 00:05:28.265
There's nothing in here.

115
00:05:28.265 --> 00:05:31.185
I'm not connected because we don't
allow anonymous access to that machine,

116
00:05:31.185 --> 00:05:33.065
it's gotta be authenticated access.

117
00:05:33.065 --> 00:05:37.445
And so I've got a little Connect As
button here we can use to provide

118
00:05:37.445 --> 00:05:41.755
a registered user name and password to be
able to connect to that system, all right?

119
00:05:41.755 --> 00:05:45.615
So when you connect to resources on the
network, some are going to be anonymous,

120
00:05:45.615 --> 00:05:48.625
that you can just connect to, and
you'll get certain levels of access.

121
00:05:48.625 --> 00:05:51.690
Others ones will require a username and
a password.

122
00:05:51.690 --> 00:05:54.970
And depending on the type of system,
it may be expecting that username and

123
00:05:54.970 --> 00:05:59.330
password in different formats, so as the
client, we just have to be aware of that.

124
00:05:59.330 --> 00:06:01.960
If it's Mac to Mac, like I'm doing
right here, it's super easy.

125
00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:04.260
We just go under our Shared section,

126
00:06:04.260 --> 00:06:08.980
we find the system we want to connect
to and we click on it, right?

127
00:06:08.980 --> 00:06:10.680
And we might need to hit Connect As.

128
00:06:10.680 --> 00:06:12.190
If you're in an Open Directory
environment,

129
00:06:12.190 --> 00:06:13.580
you're already authenticated and
you're fine.

130
00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:15.620
But if you're not in Open Directory,
you'll have to hit Connect As and

131
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:16.640
put in your username and password.

132
00:06:16.640 --> 00:06:18.730
And you get connected up, and that's that.

133
00:06:18.730 --> 00:06:22.680
So being on the client side is not
a big deal, if it's Mac to Mac.

134
00:06:23.710 --> 00:06:30.600
But what if I'm connecting Mac to Linux or
Mac to Windows?

135
00:06:30.600 --> 00:06:32.870
Well, that's where things
get a little different.

136
00:06:32.870 --> 00:06:35.170
The protocol that's being used here,
I mentioned Bonjour, right?

137
00:06:35.170 --> 00:06:36.500
Bonjour is a discovery protocol.

138
00:06:36.500 --> 00:06:40.460
That's how we find people on the network,
but that's not how we transfer files.

139
00:06:40.460 --> 00:06:42.090
Once you find them,

140
00:06:42.090 --> 00:06:45.990
Mac talking to Mac will exchange
files using something called AFP.

141
00:06:45.990 --> 00:06:48.600
AFP is the Apple File Protocol.

142
00:06:48.600 --> 00:06:51.360
And it's just a simple file protocol
that Apple made that allows us to

143
00:06:51.360 --> 00:06:53.490
exchange files over the network,
works great, right?

144
00:06:53.490 --> 00:06:56.930
That's AFP and that's what I was
technically using there when I browsed and

145
00:06:56.930 --> 00:06:58.390
saw that content.

146
00:06:58.390 --> 00:07:03.700
But Windows machines don't run AFP,
Linux machines don't run AFP.

147
00:07:03.700 --> 00:07:07.440
So if I want to talk to them, I'm going
to have to use a different protocol.

148
00:07:07.440 --> 00:07:11.930
And fortunately, your Mac, it's already
got those protocols built into it.

149
00:07:11.930 --> 00:07:13.780
Let me show you what I mean there.

150
00:07:13.780 --> 00:07:16.550
So, when I browse into the Finder,

151
00:07:16.550 --> 00:07:21.610
I'm only seeing devices that can
be discovered by Bonjour, right?

152
00:07:21.610 --> 00:07:23.530
But I'm not gonna find

103

104

105
00:05:30.300 --> 00:05:34.780

00:05:34.780 --> 00:05:36.660

00:05:39.050 --> 00:05:43.150

00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:51.240

But Google, Yahoo!, AOL,

00:06:04.645 --> 00:06:07.680

00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:11.990
So POP3, the Post Office Protocol,

00:06:11.990 --> 00:06:16.650

00:06:16.650 --> 00:06:18.880

But IMAP4 is the other one.

00:06:39.462 --> 00:06:43.290

130
00:06:46.520 --> 00:06:48.526

131
00:06:48.526 --> 00:06:51.260
So, it downloads the emails and then
removes them from the server which means

133
00:06:56.540 --> 00:06:59.840

downloads the five emails, the iPhone and

00:06:59.840 --> 00:07:02.468

135
00:07:02.468 --> 00:07:05.130
So POP3 is not very friendly
when you have multiple devices,

136
00:07:05.130 --> 00:07:06.390
it makes things difficult.

137
00:07:06.390 --> 00:07:09.460
Now they've changed it a little
bit over the years to say like

138
00:07:09.460 --> 00:07:11.860
download the emails but
leave them on the server.

139
00:07:11.860 --> 00:07:14.880
But then we still have other problems of
like whether they get marked read and so

00:07:14.880 --> 00:07:17.177

00:07:32.500 --> 00:07:34.390
All these little folders

00:07:36.570 --> 00:07:37.946

00:07:37.946 --> 00:07:38.929

00:07:38.929 --> 00:07:42.700

00:07:43.785 --> 00:07:46.633

00:07:46.633 --> 00:07:49.886

00:07:49.886 --> 00:07:53.726

00:07:58.115 --> 00:08:02.221

00:31:05.940 --> 00:31:07.500
So you don't have to use these, but

635
00:31:07.500 --> 00:31:09.510
these are nice because they
integrate with the operating system.

636
00:31:09.510 --> 00:31:11.920
And so now, if I'm in a web browser and

637
00:31:11.920 --> 00:31:14.490
I hit email this link,
it'll launch this email client.

638
00:31:14.490 --> 00:31:17.010
It won't necessarily launch a third
party client in some scenarios, so

639
00:31:17.010 --> 00:31:20.150
you got to kinda pick and choose what
you want as far as functionality.

640
00:31:20.150 --> 00:31:23.200
But as far as integrating
with collaboration services,

641
00:31:23.200 --> 00:31:25.130
Apple's pretty much got you set up.

642
00:31:25.130 --> 00:31:28.540
Email's the critical one, and
you need to remember iMap, Pop3, and

643
00:31:28.540 --> 00:31:31.670
SMTP, those three protocols,
they're important.

644
00:31:31.670 --> 00:31:35.370
After that, all the other services
are kinda extras that are a nice bonus.

645
00:31:35.370 --> 00:31:38.340
Contacts and calendars are the two
that will show up on the exam.

646
00:31:38.340 --> 00:31:41.350
And be aware that iCloud and
Exchange will give you those.

647
00:31:41.350 --> 00:31:42.920
The other services just do email.

648
00:31:42.920 --> 00:31:45.250
So that's a bit of a challenge
that you might bump into.

649
00:31:45.250 --> 00:31:47.630
>> Well, that's awesome stuff any way,
shape or form.

650
00:31:47.630 --> 00:31:49.280
The good news is, like Don said, yeah,

651
00:31:49.280 --> 00:31:52.630
there are third party options you can go
with that might be a little bit better.

652
00:31:52.630 --> 00:31:53.800
They might be a lot better.

653
00:31:53.800 --> 00:31:55.230
That could be the case.

654
00:31:55.230 --> 00:31:57.900
But, if you're adjusting something
that's gonna get you working.

655
00:31:57.900 --> 00:32:01.850
They already have that built into
the operating system itself.

656
00:32:01.850 --> 00:32:04.450
So, go ahead and
use it if that's all you need it for.

657
00:32:04.450 --> 00:32:06.360
The basic functionality
is there waiting for you.

658
00:32:06.360 --> 00:32:07.680
Just turn it on and use it.

659
00:32:07.680 --> 00:32:10.500
And of course,
if you're trying to pass this exam,

660
00:32:10.500 --> 00:32:13.680
it's probably a good idea if
you're familiar with that as well.

661
00:32:13.680 --> 00:32:16.190
Don, thanks for stopping by and
explaining these concepts.

662
00:32:16.190 --> 00:32:19.940
Showing us how to use these cool little
features of our operating system.

663
00:32:19.940 --> 00:32:22.990
And thank you guys for watching, and we've
come to the end of another great episode.

664
00:32:22.990 --> 00:32:25.310
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it,
signing off for ITProTV,

665
00:32:25.310 --> 00:32:26.677
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

666
00:32:26.677 --> 00:32:27.652
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

667
00:32:27.652 --> 00:32:29.672
>> We'll see you next time.

668
00:32:29.672 --> 00:32:37.470
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate some of the great security features that are apart of the Mac operating system, so that you can support them inside of your mixed environments. They start by looking at the System Integration Protection(SIP) that "sandboxes" access to the system. Then they show you how to  utilize the Password Assistant to help you create secure passwords. Finally, they explain how to use 2-factor/multi-factor authentication for even greater user security.
episodes.title: Security Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.086 --> 00:00:10.086
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.113 --> 00:00:17.060
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:17.060 --> 00:00:18.430
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.430 --> 00:00:23.050
in today's episode, well we're continuing
on with our Mac integration basic series.

5
00:00:23.050 --> 00:00:26.190
Joining us, back in the studio again
today, our guiding star in that endeavor.

6
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:27.680
It is none other then our good friend Mr.
Don Pezet.

7
00:00:27.680 --> 00:00:28.730
Don, welcome back sir.

8
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:30.890
>> Thanks for
having me back on the show, Daniel,

9
00:00:30.890 --> 00:00:33.850
and ready to jump right back in
the world of Mac integration basics.

10
00:00:33.850 --> 00:00:36.715
In this episode, we're going to
change gears just a little bit.

11
00:00:36.715 --> 00:00:39.875
In the other episodes we've always been
talking about how to get our Mac to

12
00:00:39.875 --> 00:00:43.975
integrate with other systems on
the network, usually Windows machines.

13
00:00:43.975 --> 00:00:46.225
In this one we're gonna step
back from that a second, and

14
00:00:46.225 --> 00:00:49.425
we're gonna look at some of
the security features in Mac OS.

15
00:00:49.425 --> 00:00:50.945
Now I know what you're thinking, like hey,

16
00:00:50.945 --> 00:00:53.455
this is just security,
it's not integrating at all, is it?

17
00:00:53.455 --> 00:00:56.465
Well, security features
are a double-edged sword.

18
00:00:56.465 --> 00:01:00.440
On one hand,
they secure your system and protect it.

19
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:01.870
On the other hand,

20
00:01:01.870 --> 00:01:05.610
they make it hard to integrate with other
systems cuz we block so much stuff.

21
00:01:05.610 --> 00:01:08.670
Now that doesn't mean you want
to turn all these things off.

22
00:01:08.670 --> 00:01:10.651
You need to be familiar with each and

23
00:01:10.651 --> 00:01:13.369
every security feature
that's a part of Mac OS.

24
00:01:13.369 --> 00:01:17.588
And what it does and
how to safely use it on the network.

25
00:01:17.588 --> 00:01:20.350
When it's okay to say, you know what,
I'm going to turn that feature off.

26
00:01:20.350 --> 00:01:23.820
And when it's not okay, when you
need to have that feature turned on.

27
00:01:23.820 --> 00:01:27.400
So while its not directly integrating,
everything we're about to talk about in

28
00:01:27.400 --> 00:01:30.570
this episode is something that can block
us integrating with other systems.

29
00:01:30.570 --> 00:01:32.000
So that's why we need to be aware of it.

30
00:01:32.000 --> 00:01:36.800
And this episode is, it's kind of
like a potluck of security features,

31
00:01:36.800 --> 00:01:40.830
a virtual cornucopia of features
that we can turn on and off.

32
00:01:40.830 --> 00:01:42.920
And most of them are all
ready turned on for us.

33
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:45.730
We just need to be aware of their names
and their functionality for the exam.

34
00:01:45.730 --> 00:01:47.920
So it's gonna be a strange episode.

35
00:01:47.920 --> 00:01:50.110
It's more than likely way more than
we'd get through in one episode.

36
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:52.100
So we'll probably break this up
over two or three episodes so

37
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:53.170
we can get through each one.

38
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:57.660
But you'll be surprised all the really
cool security technologies that are under

39
00:01:57.660 --> 00:02:00.600
the hood in Mac OS that most
people don't even know about.

40
00:02:00.600 --> 00:02:02.080
Don't even realize.

41
00:02:02.080 --> 00:02:05.210
Sometimes that's a good thing, it's
security that doesn't get in your way.

42
00:02:05.210 --> 00:02:08.050
Other times it's a bad thing because it's
security features that aren't turned on

43
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:08.650
by default.

44
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:11.250
And unless you know about them,
you don't know to turn them on and

45
00:02:11.250 --> 00:02:12.740
that means you're not
benefiting from them.

46
00:02:12.740 --> 00:02:14.809
So these are definitely things
that we need to be aware of.

47
00:02:15.940 --> 00:02:18.200
So let's kick this turkey off.

48
00:02:18.200 --> 00:02:21.910
The first one we're gonna start with is
one of those invisible security features.

49
00:02:21.910 --> 00:02:24.726
It's one that's turned on
by default on Mac OS, and

50
00:02:24.726 --> 00:02:27.160
it's called System Integrity Protection.

51
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:33.190
System Integrity Protection,
it should be easier to say,

52
00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:40.030
is a special feature of Mac OS where every
program that gets run, gets sandboxed.

53
00:02:40.030 --> 00:02:42.000
Now, I threw up my little aircodes,

54
00:02:42.000 --> 00:02:44.440
I stressed the word Sandbox
because if you take the exam and

55
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:47.760
you don't see the word Sandbox once,
then it's like winning the lottery.

56
00:02:47.760 --> 00:02:49.790
It is gonna turn up on the exam somewhere.

57
00:02:49.790 --> 00:02:55.280
Sandboxing is where you isolate
applications from other applications.

58
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:58.530
When a hacker breaks into your system or
some kind of network vulnerability

59
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:02.430
gets exploited, it's typically
a vulnerability found in one program.

60
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:04.530
But, once they break through that program,

61
00:03:04.530 --> 00:03:07.490
they can then leapfrog throughout
the whole rest of your system.

62
00:03:07.490 --> 00:03:10.460
When we sand box an application,
the application runs,

63
00:03:10.460 --> 00:03:13.340
the vulnerability might be there,
the hacker breaks into that application.

64
00:03:13.340 --> 00:03:15.800
And then they're stuck
in that little world,

65
00:03:15.800 --> 00:03:17.440
the little world of that application.

66
00:03:17.440 --> 00:03:20.330
And they're not able to access
the rest of your resources.

67
00:03:20.330 --> 00:03:22.680
It's really a pretty
complex thing to set up.

68
00:03:22.680 --> 00:03:27.060
If you work in the Unix world or the Linux
world, you have chroot that lets you

69
00:03:27.060 --> 00:03:30.530
change the root of various applications
to create these little jails for them.

70
00:03:30.530 --> 00:03:31.945
And it's kinda hard to do.

71
00:03:31.945 --> 00:03:33.940
Well, in Mac OS it's done for
you automatically.

72
00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:34.760
It's already done,

73
00:03:34.760 --> 00:03:37.750
as you launch these applications,
they run in their own little space.

74
00:03:37.750 --> 00:03:39.760
And for most of us,
we never even notice it.

75
00:03:39.760 --> 00:03:42.150
It just happens in the background,
and that's it.

76
00:03:42.150 --> 00:03:44.680
But there are times where we do see it.

77
00:03:44.680 --> 00:03:48.180
You see it anytime you go
to install an application.

78
00:03:48.180 --> 00:03:51.020
Because when you install an application,
what's it have to do?

79
00:03:51.020 --> 00:03:55.340
It has to write to some
sensitive areas on the computer.

80
00:03:55.340 --> 00:03:58.260
And those sensitive areas are protected.

81
00:03:58.260 --> 00:03:59.889
Let me show you what I mean.

82
00:03:59.889 --> 00:04:01.839
If I browse into my finder, and

83
00:04:01.839 --> 00:04:05.770
I go to my Macintosh hard drive,
I only see four folders.

84
00:04:05.770 --> 00:04:07.420
My hard drive looks pretty empty.

85
00:04:08.470 --> 00:04:09.879
These four folders are important though.

86
00:04:09.879 --> 00:04:12.390
Applications, that's where my programs go.

87
00:04:12.390 --> 00:04:14.500
If I put an application in
the Application folder,

88
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:16.560
that's where I store it so it can run.

89
00:04:16.560 --> 00:04:19.500
But if one application gets compromised,

90
00:04:19.500 --> 00:04:22.820
in theory it could start
modifying other applications.

91
00:04:22.820 --> 00:04:26.890
And so I might've gotten
a malware installed via email,

92
00:04:26.890 --> 00:04:29.450
and then it goes and
it modifies my web browser.

93
00:04:29.450 --> 00:04:33.130
And now every time I browse to a website,
it's displaying pop-up ads and

94
00:04:33.130 --> 00:04:33.860
things like that.

95
00:04:33.860 --> 00:04:35.620
One application has modified another.

96
00:04:35.620 --> 00:04:38.510
I don't want programs to be
able to write to applications.

97
00:04:38.510 --> 00:04:39.090
Very sensitive.

98
00:04:40.120 --> 00:04:43.530
Library that's where all of
my system preferences are.

99
00:04:43.530 --> 00:04:45.630
All the configuration for my system.

100
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:47.930
All the security features
we're about to talk about,

101
00:04:47.930 --> 00:04:50.020
they're configured inside
of that library folder.

102
00:04:50.020 --> 00:04:52.890
And so if I get infected with malware and

103
00:04:52.890 --> 00:04:57.570
it modifies other systems,
it could turn off security features.

104
00:04:57.570 --> 00:04:59.370
So it's another one that
I want to be protecting.

105
00:04:59.370 --> 00:05:01.900
But I can't lock it completely down.

106
00:05:01.900 --> 00:05:03.970
Because every program has
their own preferences, right?

107
00:05:03.970 --> 00:05:06.250
If I go on to the Library folder, and

108
00:05:06.250 --> 00:05:09.520
I find the Preferences folder
which is buried in here somewhere.

109
00:05:09.520 --> 00:05:10.940
There.

110
00:05:10.940 --> 00:05:13.700
Every application has its
own set of preferences.

111
00:05:13.700 --> 00:05:17.060
So, if I browse around,
that's an interesting effect there.

112
00:05:17.060 --> 00:05:18.860
So, if I browse around in here and
start to look,

113
00:05:18.860 --> 00:05:21.150
most of the stuff is Apple stuff, right?

114
00:05:21.150 --> 00:05:22.560
But if I keep looking.

115
00:05:22.560 --> 00:05:25.310
I guess I really don't have any third
party software installed on here.

116
00:05:25.310 --> 00:05:28.140
But, my third party software would all
have their own preference files too.

117
00:05:28.140 --> 00:05:31.290
And those programs need to be able
to write to their own preferences.

118
00:05:31.290 --> 00:05:34.550
But they shouldn't be allowed to
write to other programs' preferences.

119
00:05:34.550 --> 00:05:37.870
That needs to be isolated and
protected access.

120
00:05:37.870 --> 00:05:42.180
That's exactly what
the System Integrity Protection is doing.

121
00:05:42.180 --> 00:05:46.030
It's restricting the access that
people have to these various folders.

122
00:05:46.030 --> 00:05:48.090
And there's a lot more than these.

123
00:05:48.090 --> 00:05:50.580
I just see these four folders
when I look at my hard drive, but

124
00:05:50.580 --> 00:05:53.490
if I drop into the terminal,
let's have some fun here.

125
00:05:53.490 --> 00:05:56.470
So I'm gonna drop into the terminal,
I'm gonna change into my root.

126
00:05:56.470 --> 00:06:00.340
And I'm gonna go do a quick ls- la so
I'm gonna see everything.

127
00:06:00.340 --> 00:06:06.790
You'll see that there's a lot more folders
in my root than what I saw in the finder.

128
00:06:06.790 --> 00:06:11.330
The finder showed me Applications,
Library, Users,

129
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:15.910
and what was the other one, Application,
Library, System, and Users.

130
00:06:15.910 --> 00:06:18.360
Did I mention System?

131
00:06:18.360 --> 00:06:19.790
System's kind of important.

132
00:06:19.790 --> 00:06:21.090
That's where Mac OS is.

133
00:06:21.090 --> 00:06:22.770
That's where the operating system is.

134
00:06:22.770 --> 00:06:27.150
So if malware gets installed, it would
love to modify the operating system.

135
00:06:27.150 --> 00:06:29.500
It can have it do all
sorts of crazy things.

136
00:06:29.500 --> 00:06:31.360
And that would be really, really bad news.

137
00:06:31.360 --> 00:06:33.420
We definitely don't want that.

138
00:06:33.420 --> 00:06:35.080
If you're ever bored,

139
00:06:35.080 --> 00:06:39.450
go check out the ITPro TV blog cuz we
did a special on the KeyRanger malware.

140
00:06:39.450 --> 00:06:42.400
And I showed in there how once
your machine was infected,

141
00:06:42.400 --> 00:06:44.980
it started dropping files
in different places.

142
00:06:44.980 --> 00:06:47.040
Most of which were in
the Library folder and so

143
00:06:47.040 --> 00:06:50.980
it was dropping files into places where
it shouldn't have normally had access to.

144
00:06:50.980 --> 00:06:54.360
But it got that access because
we ran the program and

145
00:06:54.360 --> 00:06:56.180
bypassed System Integrity Protection.

146
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:59.630
So that's a kind of
an interesting way of seeing that.

147
00:06:59.630 --> 00:07:05.730
But all these other folders are pretty
important too, like /bin, and /sbin.

148
00:07:05.730 --> 00:07:09.380
Those are where the binaries for
the underlying BSD system reside.

149
00:07:09.380 --> 00:07:10.860
Those are really low level.

150
00:07:10.860 --> 00:07:12.210
End users don't normally see those.

151
00:07:12.210 --> 00:07:15.050
And if malware can modify them,
that's a big problem.

152
00:07:15.050 --> 00:07:18.970
So a lot of these folders are protected
by System Integrity Protection.

153
00:07:18.970 --> 00:07:21.970
When you run a program,
they're not allowed to touch these.

154
00:07:21.970 --> 00:07:23.490
If they try it gets blocked.

155
00:07:23.490 --> 00:07:25.660
And that stops malware from working.

156
00:07:25.660 --> 00:07:27.200
They can't modify these folders.

157
00:07:27.200 --> 00:07:29.700
But there's some folders we
do want them to write to.

158
00:07:29.700 --> 00:07:31.480
We want them to be able to
write to their own preferences.

159
00:07:31.480 --> 00:07:33.960
We want them to be able to write to
their own little library folder.

160
00:07:33.960 --> 00:07:35.510
Where they have their application support.

161
00:07:35.510 --> 00:07:37.610
So those are allowed.

162
00:07:37.610 --> 00:07:40.870
System Integrity Protection is
a service that's configured by Apple.

163
00:07:40.870 --> 00:07:43.980
That says here's what you're
going to have access to.

164
00:07:43.980 --> 00:07:45.890
And for the most part, it's invisible.

165
00:07:45.890 --> 00:07:47.280
Most people don't even know
about these folders, so

166
00:07:47.280 --> 00:07:48.540
they don't care if they're protected or
not.

167
00:07:48.540 --> 00:07:52.070
If they don't even know the folder exists,
what do they care, right?

168
00:07:52.070 --> 00:07:55.855
But where we see it as an end user is
really through part of what's called

169
00:07:55.855 --> 00:07:56.811
the Gatekeeper.

170
00:07:56.811 --> 00:08:00.975
When you go to install a program, so
let's say I go into my computer, and

171
00:08:00.975 --> 00:08:02.838
I wanna install Google Chrome.

172
00:08:02.838 --> 00:08:03.523
Right.

173
00:08:03.523 --> 00:08:07.258
If I want to install Google Chrome I
can just take it and

174
00:08:07.258 --> 00:08:09.090
I can mount that DMG file.

175
00:08:09.090 --> 00:08:12.290
So, I'm going to mount that DMG file and

176
00:08:12.290 --> 00:08:16.540
then I just need to drag Google Chrome and
drop it in the applications folder.

177
00:08:16.540 --> 00:08:20.090
Now, am I allowed to write
to the applications folder?

178
00:08:20.090 --> 00:08:20.840
I am.

179
00:08:20.840 --> 00:08:22.090
If I'm an administrator I am.

180
00:08:22.090 --> 00:08:24.200
If I'm an end user, I'm not.

181
00:08:24.200 --> 00:08:28.430
If I'm a regular user you're not allowed
to write to the applications folder.

182
00:08:28.430 --> 00:08:32.370
So when you go to install Chrome and
it asks you to drag Chrome and

183
00:08:32.370 --> 00:08:37.135
drop it into applications, if you're
an administrator that'll get written to be

184
00:08:37.135 --> 00:08:40.270
/applicationsfolder and
I'm an administrator,

185
00:08:40.270 --> 00:08:42.280
see how it didn't prompt me for
a password or anything like that.

186
00:08:42.280 --> 00:08:43.880
I have those permissions.

187
00:08:43.880 --> 00:08:47.260
For an end user though,
system integrity protection kicks in and

188
00:08:47.260 --> 00:08:49.480
says you're not allowed
to write to that folder.

189
00:08:49.480 --> 00:08:52.700
So instead,
we're going to virtualize that folder and

190
00:08:52.700 --> 00:08:55.380
we're going to put it in your
own applications folder.

191
00:08:55.380 --> 00:09:00.860
Going back to the file system, Macs
are supposed to be magical and easy and

192
00:09:00.860 --> 00:09:06.990
all GUI, so I hate to do too much in the
terminal but when I look at my root drive.

193
00:09:06.990 --> 00:09:08.510
You've got the applications folder.

194

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the many different ways to connect your Mac to a printer. They begin with the most simplistic method of connecting via USB. Then they show you how to connect to a network printer using AirPrint as well as directly using TCP/IP. Finally they look at connecting to a shared printer on a Windows system and sharing your printer from your Mac.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to configure your Mac to allow for instant messaging. They start by demonstrating how to configure chat from Mac to Mac with AOL Instant Messenger, Yahoo, Google, and Bonjour. Then they show you how to setup a chat server using Jabber messaging built-in to the Server App.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don tackle the scenario of migrating a user and their data from a Windows based PC to a Mac. They show you how to use the Migration Assistant that is built-in to El Capitan to automate the process of finding and moving user data over a network connection.

00:06:35.358 --> 00:06:40.378

00:06:40.378 --> 00:06:42.510

00:06:42.510 --> 00:06:45.690

00:06:45.690 --> 00:06:49.550

00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:50.530

00:06:50.530 --> 00:06:54.010

00:06:54.010 --> 00:06:57.120

00:06:57.120 --> 00:06:58.070

00:07:16.560 --> 00:07:19.030

00:07:19.030 --> 00:07:20.040

00:07:20.040 --> 00:07:20.680

00:07:20.680 --> 00:07:22.220
