617
00:28:32.230 --> 00:28:33.981
>> We'll see you next time.

618
00:28:33.981 --> 00:28:41.710
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss the importance of backing up your data. They demonstrate backing up using Time Machine to a removable hard drive, or a network share. They also discuss alternative backup solutions that may be useful.
episodes.title: Time Machine
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.461 --> 00:00:10.461
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.168 --> 00:00:16.640
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:16.640 --> 00:00:18.720
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:18.720 --> 00:00:22.720
in today's episode, we're continuing on
with our Mac integration basics series.

5
00:00:22.720 --> 00:00:26.500
Joining us back in the studio today is
our good friend and mentor Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:26.500 --> 00:00:27.320
Don welcome back sir.

7
00:00:27.320 --> 00:00:28.070
How are you doing?

8
00:00:28.070 --> 00:00:29.590
I'm doing great Daniel thanks for
having me back.

9
00:00:29.590 --> 00:00:32.560
And ready to jump back into
the world of Mac integration basics.

10
00:00:32.560 --> 00:00:37.160
In this episode, we're going to be taking
a look at time machine inside of Mac OS.

11
00:00:37.160 --> 00:00:40.410
And let me tell you this is one of those
services that if you're not using it you

12
00:00:40.410 --> 00:00:41.430
absolutely should.

13
00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:43.840
Time machine is really pretty sweet.

14
00:00:43.840 --> 00:00:47.800
At its heart, it's just a simple way for
us to back up our data so

15
00:00:47.800 --> 00:00:50.900
we can quickly restore if we ever
have some kind of a failure.

16
00:00:50.900 --> 00:00:51.765
Do we get DeLoreans?

17
00:00:51.765 --> 00:00:52.868
That would be sweet.

18
00:00:52.868 --> 00:00:56.546
That would be awesome.
[LAUGH] So, with Time Machine,

19
00:00:56.546 --> 00:01:00.550
let's think of this as a story,
let's go back in time.

20
00:01:00.550 --> 00:01:02.790
I know I had this happen to me
once where I was in college,

21
00:01:02.790 --> 00:01:06.260
and I was using my computer and
it started acting a little funny and

22
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:08.820
I rebooted it and
then it wouldn't boot up.

23
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:12.020
And then I found out
the hard drive had failed.

24
00:01:12.020 --> 00:01:13.190
Right, hard drives fail.

25
00:01:13.190 --> 00:01:14.530
They don't last forever.

26
00:01:14.530 --> 00:01:17.050
Usually you're lucky if you can get three
years out of the darn things if they're

27
00:01:17.050 --> 00:01:20.660
SSD if they're spinning usually
you know you don't get forever.

28
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:21.800
Eventually they fail.

29
00:01:21.800 --> 00:01:24.348
And when they do fail what
happens to your data?

30
00:01:24.348 --> 00:01:29.200
Well, maybe,
maybe you can recover data off of it.

31
00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:31.210
But most of the time you
just lose your information.

32
00:01:31.210 --> 00:01:34.120
And if you don't have a backup,
that's a real bad place to be.

33
00:01:34.120 --> 00:01:37.550
Now, thanks to cloud technologies and
a lot of the services we have these days,

34
00:01:37.550 --> 00:01:39.640
like if you're using your iCloud storage,

35
00:01:39.640 --> 00:01:42.000
then maybe all your data is backed up
already and you don't worry about it.

36
00:01:42.000 --> 00:01:44.280
Right, there's plenty of
alternatives to Time Machine.

37
00:01:44.280 --> 00:01:48.990
There's things like Dropbox and iCloud and
OneDrive I don't like to talk about

38
00:01:48.990 --> 00:01:51.850
that one, and some of the others out there
that can back your data up to the cloud.

39
00:01:51.850 --> 00:01:54.510
Those are great, but
if you don't have those.

40
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:56.030
If you don't have a good
backup solution and

41
00:01:56.030 --> 00:01:58.350
your hard drive fails
you're going to lose data.

42
00:01:58.350 --> 00:02:01.750
And you know it's not even necessarily
just about a hard drive failing.

43
00:02:01.750 --> 00:02:04.610
Maybe it's just I do something
accidental like I delete a file.

44
00:02:04.610 --> 00:02:06.510
I deleted a file a week ago and

45
00:02:06.510 --> 00:02:10.670
then I realized today shoot I
really need that file, it's gone.

46
00:02:10.670 --> 00:02:12.440
Well, if I deleted it, where does it go?

47
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:14.810
It goes into the trash, right?

48
00:02:14.810 --> 00:02:16.900
So I can always get it out of the trash,
if it's still there,

49
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:22.150
if I haven't emptied the trash on my Mac,
or if I've deleted it and

50
00:02:22.150 --> 00:02:26.180
it's gone from the trash,
then I'm out of luck, right?

51
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:28.380
Or what if I overwrite a file?

52
00:02:28.380 --> 00:02:31.650
If I open up a word document, and
I deleted a paragraph out, and

53
00:02:31.650 --> 00:02:33.370
I save the document, right?

54
00:02:33.370 --> 00:02:36.060
Well I over-wrote the existing file,
so it's not in the trash.

55
00:02:36.060 --> 00:02:36.930
It's just gone.

56
00:02:36.930 --> 00:02:40.610
I've lost that paragraph forever, and
if I want it back, well tough luck.

57
00:02:40.610 --> 00:02:43.370
So my hard drive didn't fail but
I lost data.

58
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:44.490
That's happens.

59
00:02:44.490 --> 00:02:46.430
Time Machine protects us from both.

60
00:02:46.430 --> 00:02:48.530
When you lose a hard drive,
when you have hard drive failure, or

61
00:02:48.530 --> 00:02:51.160
when you just lose data,
it'll help you recover both.

62
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:55.020
And so it's a great idea to have it set up
and running and backing up your system.

63
00:02:55.020 --> 00:02:56.860
So in this show I'm gonna
walk you through that.

64
00:02:56.860 --> 00:03:01.180
But different ways that we can use
Time Machine and make it work for us.

65
00:03:01.180 --> 00:03:01.930
I use it all the time.

66
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:05.740
It's saved my bacon a few times so
it's definitely something you want to use.

67
00:03:05.740 --> 00:03:08.700
All right, well let's just start
with basic Time Machine 101, right.

68
00:03:08.700 --> 00:03:11.100
So I wanna get Time Machine
enabled on my Mac.

69
00:03:11.100 --> 00:03:12.140
Well I'm not running it.

70
00:03:12.140 --> 00:03:15.340
So I've got this Mac here, and actually
I had this one set up as a server,

71
00:03:15.340 --> 00:03:18.250
which just means it's Mac OS
with the server app installed.

72
00:03:18.250 --> 00:03:21.280
You definitely want to back up a server,
but I probably want to

73
00:03:21.280 --> 00:03:24.160
back up work stations too so
you configure this on work stations.

74
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:26.470
I run it on my own laptop,
running it right now.

75
00:03:27.500 --> 00:03:32.290
The only you really need is some
kind of external storage, right?

76
00:03:32.290 --> 00:03:35.240
You don't want to back up to your own
hard drive, you always want to back up to

77
00:03:35.240 --> 00:03:38.290
an external device because your
internal hard drive could die.

78
00:03:38.290 --> 00:03:41.410
So if I'm backing up my data to the
internal hard drive, what good is that?

79
00:03:41.410 --> 00:03:43.220
It's no good.
It's not going to help you.

80
00:03:43.220 --> 00:03:44.520
So we need an external device.

81
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:46.930
And so you'll see I've got two
hard drives in this server.

82
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:50.550
I've got my Macintosh HD, and
then I've added a second storage drive.

83
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:54.380
Now, if you have a Mac Pro or
even one of the older Mac Minis,

84
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:56.320
you can fit two hard drives inside of it.

85
00:03:56.320 --> 00:03:58.170
So it doesn't have to be
an external hard drive,

86
00:03:58.170 --> 00:03:59.909
it could be a second drive inside of it.

87
00:04:01.070 --> 00:04:06.080
But if you have a MacBook Pro or a newer
Mac mini they don't have any space.

88
00:04:06.080 --> 00:04:06.970
Or even an iMac.

89
00:04:06.970 --> 00:04:08.710
There's no space to add
a second hard drive.

90
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:10.660
It's going to have to be
an external device, and

91
00:04:10.660 --> 00:04:12.830
that's kind of what I'm
using here on my laptop.

92
00:04:12.830 --> 00:04:14.410
So, here I've got this second drive.

93
00:04:14.410 --> 00:04:18.610
It's a 500 gig drive and
it's just sitting there doing nothing.

94
00:04:18.610 --> 00:04:20.650
Well, any time you add
external storage and

95
00:04:20.650 --> 00:04:24.800
you format it, your Mac is gonna try and
turn on Time Machine for you.

96
00:04:24.800 --> 00:04:29.690
So, for example, if I go into Disk Utility
and I choose that storage drive and

97
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:31.340
I'm going to erase it, right.

98
00:04:31.340 --> 00:04:32.560
And I'm just gonna call it Time Machine.

99
00:04:32.560 --> 00:04:33.380
Now, the name doesn't matter.

100
00:04:33.380 --> 00:04:34.410
I can call it whatever I want.

101
00:04:34.410 --> 00:04:35.990
I can call it Bob.

102
00:04:35.990 --> 00:04:37.580
It doesn't matter about the name.

103
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:41.470
Whenever you format a disk,
if you're not already using Time Machine,

104
00:04:41.470 --> 00:04:43.310
the system is gonna ask
you if you wanna use it.

105
00:04:43.310 --> 00:04:45.190
See here.
I just got my pop up, right.

106
00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:48.630
And it's saying, hey I just
noticed you added another drive,

107
00:04:48.630 --> 00:04:50.870
would you like to use
it with Time Machine?

108
00:04:50.870 --> 00:04:54.510
And if you do, you just hit Use
as backup disk, and you're done.

109
00:04:54.510 --> 00:04:57.880
Easiest thing in the planet,
you're now backed up, all right?

110
00:04:57.880 --> 00:05:00.235
Or you can say, don't use or
or decide later.

111
00:05:00.235 --> 00:05:02.245
I don't know,
maybe I'll make up my mind later.

112
00:05:02.245 --> 00:05:03.725
I'm gonna say don't use for

113
00:05:03.725 --> 00:05:06.685
right now, because this use as
backup disk button is too easy.

114
00:05:06.685 --> 00:05:08.235
You just push it and
everything's done, and

115
00:05:08.235 --> 00:05:09.360
I wanna make it look like this is hard.

116
00:05:09.360 --> 00:05:11.715
[LAUGHS] So I'm gonna choose don't use.

117
00:05:11.715 --> 00:05:13.285
It's not that I want to make it hard,

118
00:05:13.285 --> 00:05:15.245
it's that I want to show you
guys each of the steps involved.

119
00:05:15.245 --> 00:05:16.975
So I'm gonna say don't use.

120
00:05:16.975 --> 00:05:17.810
All right.

121
00:05:17.810 --> 00:05:20.070
Now I've got this extra
drive sitting here.

122
00:05:20.070 --> 00:05:21.940
But it's not a Time Machine disk yet.

123
00:05:21.940 --> 00:05:23.200
Now how do I know that?

124
00:05:23.200 --> 00:05:24.130
Cuz of the icon.

125
00:05:24.130 --> 00:05:25.890
The icons just a regular hard drive icon.

126
00:05:25.890 --> 00:05:29.910
When its set up for Time Machine it'll
actually change into a blue disk with

127
00:05:29.910 --> 00:05:34.580
a little time machine logo on it so it's
not being used for Time Machine right now.

128
00:05:34.580 --> 00:05:35.340
That's my first hint.

129
00:05:35.340 --> 00:05:37.280
My second hint is that the drive is empty.

130
00:05:37.280 --> 00:05:39.860
So if it is a Time Machine disk,
I'm not doing a very good job.

131
00:05:39.860 --> 00:05:42.550
So it's not set up for it yet.

132
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:46.130
So what I'm going to do now is I'm
going to fire up my spotlight and

133
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:48.300
I'm going to run Time Machine.

134
00:05:48.300 --> 00:05:50.620
It's in your applications folder,
under utilities.

135
00:05:50.620 --> 00:05:53.790
I'm going to fire it up, and
the first thing its gonna do is say, hey

136
00:05:53.790 --> 00:05:57.650
you haven't selected a location for time
machine backups, we need to set it up now.

137
00:05:57.650 --> 00:05:59.560
So I'm gonna choose to
set up Time Machine.

138
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:02.360
All right now when we go to set it up,

139
00:06:02.360 --> 00:06:05.150
we're gonna have to pick the hard
drive that we want to back up to.

140
00:06:05.150 --> 00:06:07.880
So I've got select a back
up disk right here and

141
00:06:07.880 --> 00:06:12.910
I'm gonna choose that back up and
I'll pick Time Machine, okay?

142
00:06:12.910 --> 00:06:14.730
Now notice this second little note here,

143
00:06:14.730 --> 00:06:18.810
I'm gonna talk about this later in
the show, Other AirPort Time Capsule.

144
00:06:18.810 --> 00:06:22.680
Normally we're backing up to an external
drive attached to our system, but

145
00:06:22.680 --> 00:06:25.000
what if I have four or five Macs?

146
00:06:25.000 --> 00:06:28.900
I can buy the Time Capsule from Apple,
which is a wireless access point you can

147
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:33.580
plug into your network, that has either
one or two terabytes of storage in it.

148
00:06:33.580 --> 00:06:35.450
And you can back up over the network.

149
00:06:35.450 --> 00:06:38.570
I'll show you how to do that even without
a Time Capsule, later in the show.

150
00:06:40.010 --> 00:06:44.840
Now, when I pick this drive, the default
is that it's gonna back up my data and

151
00:06:44.840 --> 00:06:46.760
put it on this drive.

152
00:06:46.760 --> 00:06:49.020
And if I, let me just cancel, if you look,

153
00:06:49.020 --> 00:06:50.330
here's where it tells you
what you're going to do.

154
00:06:50.330 --> 00:06:53.820
It's going to do hourly back ups for
the past 24 hours.

155
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:56.040
When I turn this on,
it's gonna do one big backup.

156
00:06:56.040 --> 00:06:58.030
It's gonna backup my whole system.

157
00:06:58.030 --> 00:07:02.650
And then every hour it's
gonna take a backup.

158
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:06.440
Now the backup it does every
hour is not a full backup.

159
00:07:06.440 --> 00:07:10.680
So if I have 20 terabytes of data, it's
not gonna back up 20 terabytes of data.

160
00:07:10.680 --> 00:07:12.230
It will the first time.

161
00:07:12.230 --> 00:07:15.950
But every hour after that,
it's only backing up what changes.

162
00:07:15.950 --> 00:07:19.180
So just the stuff that I modify,
so the backups become very small.

163
00:07:19.180 --> 00:07:22.170
They happen very quickly, and
it does it every hour, and

164
00:07:22.170 --> 00:07:24.410
it's gonna save those for 24 hours.

165
00:07:25.410 --> 00:07:29.230
After 24 hours, it's gonna roll
those down into one backup.

166
00:07:29.230 --> 00:07:33.560
So it's saving a backup every single
day for the past month, so for

167
00:07:33.560 --> 00:07:35.120
the last 31 days.

168
00:07:35.120 --> 00:07:37.940
And then after 31 days,

169
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:43.380
it saves one backup a week for
as many weeks as it has room to store.

170
00:07:43.380 --> 00:07:45.030
Eventually your hard
drive runs out of space.

171
00:07:45.030 --> 00:07:48.887
It can't store any more backups, so it
deletes the old backups to make room for

172
00:07:48.887 --> 00:07:49.422
new ones.

173
00:07:49.422 --> 00:07:53.173
The cool part about this is I can restore
back to various points in time, so

174
00:07:53.173 --> 00:07:56.211
if I'm like man,
I deleted that file at 3 PM today.

175
00:07:56.211 --> 00:08:00.747
Well, it's 4 PM right now, so
a Time Machine backup ran.

176
00:08:00.747 --> 00:08:02.144
Let me just go back to 2 PM.

177
00:08:02.144 --> 00:08:05.190
And I can get the document
as it was at 2 PM.

178
00:08:05.190 --> 00:08:08.490
Or if I deleted it a week ago I
can go back a week and get to it.

179
00:08:08.490 --> 00:08:11.560
And I can go back as far as I can as
long as I have disk space for it.

180
00:08:11.560 --> 00:08:13.030
So that's what it's going to do.

181
00:08:13.030 --> 00:08:17.070
So when I select that backup disk and
I pick that time machine disk that I made,

182
00:08:17.070 --> 00:08:20.600
it's going to start that
first initial backup.

183
00:08:20.600 --> 00:08:23.210
It's going to backup my whole drive.

184
00:08:23.210 --> 00:08:24.840
Now before I do that,

185
00:08:24.840 --> 00:08:27.870
there's a neat little option right
here to encrypt the backups.

186
00:08:28.980 --> 00:08:33.110
If you're using an internal drive,
this may or may not be necessary for you.

187
00:08:33.110 --> 00:08:36.270
But if you're using an external drive,
this is really important,

188
00:08:36.270 --> 00:08:40.740
because what if you lose your external
drive and somebody gets a hold of it?

189
00:08:40.740 --> 00:08:42.910
All of your data is on that drive and

190
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:46.980
they can hook it up to whatever Mac they
wanted and restore it and now they've got

191
00:08:46.980 --> 00:08:51.480
an exact copy of your computer with
all your data, that's not good, right?

192
00:08:51.480 --> 00:08:55.510
Even if it's an internal drive somebody
could still steal your physical computer.

193
00:08:55.510 --> 00:08:59.030
So if you're using file vault on your main
drive you might as well use encryption on

194
00:08:59.030 --> 00:09:00.840
your time machine also to encrypt it.

195
00:09:00.840 --> 00:09:02.900
But on a external drive
it is really important.

196
00:09:02.900 --> 00:09:05.460
So I've got this external drive
hooked up to my laptop and

197
00:09:05.460 --> 00:09:09.360
I've got a big sticker on the front
of it and it says Don's Backup.

198
00:09:09.360 --> 00:09:11.370
And it's, Daniel you can vouch for me.

199
00:09:11.370 --> 00:09:13.410
It says D Pozent backup.

200
00:09:13.410 --> 00:09:15.060
D Pozent backup I lied.

201
00:09:15.060 --> 00:09:17.890
So I've got a big sticker right on there.

202
00:09:17.890 --> 00:09:20.980
Anybody could walk into this studio and
say ooh, that's Don's backup,

203
00:09:20.980 --> 00:09:22.890
that's gotta sticker on it,
it must be accurate.

204
00:09:22.890 --> 00:09:25.850
We certainly wouldn't label
something wrong around here.

205
00:09:25.850 --> 00:09:28.910
So they could take it, run home and
now they've got all my data.

206
00:09:28.910 --> 00:09:30.600
So I need to encrypt that.

207
00:09:30.600 --> 00:09:32.070
We've got that option and
we can turn it off.

208
00:09:32.070 --> 00:09:35.140
I'm going to leave it off here in
the show, only because we've only got a 30

209
00:09:35.140 --> 00:09:37.340
minute show and
I don't want to take too long with this.

210
00:09:37.340 --> 00:09:39.990
But in real life land,
I always turn that on.

211
00:09:39.990 --> 00:09:41.520
Always, always, always.

212
00:09:41.520 --> 00:09:44.360
And it will generate a recovery
key that you will need to save.

213
00:09:44.360 --> 00:09:48.080
Because if you lose that recovery key, you
won't be able to open up that backup and

214
00:09:48.080 --> 00:09:49.250
then it's like you don't have a backup.

215
00:09:49.250 --> 00:09:50.230
So that would be bad.

216
00:09:50.230 --> 00:09:52.110
But I will leave that off for now.

217
00:09:52.110 --> 00:09:53.460
All right,
I'm gonna choose to use that disk.

218
00:09:53.460 --> 00:09:55.670
And as soon as I do that,

219
00:09:55.670 --> 00:09:59.420
now it's showing that I've got
536 GB available on this disk.

220
00:09:59.420 --> 00:10:00.600
The oldest backup is none.

221
00:10:00.600 --> 00:10:01.640
The latest backup is none.

222
00:10:01.640 --> 00:10:03.900
And it's gonna do a backup in two minutes.

223

00:30:33.500 --> 00:30:36.060
>> That's about it,
definitely I would take a look at those.

612
00:30:36.060 --> 00:30:38.082
There is one other thing though,

613
00:30:38.082 --> 00:30:42.635
is sometimes you have an application
that runs on Windows that also has some

614
00:30:42.635 --> 00:30:47.551
special hardware requirement that makes
it not work in a virtual environment and

615
00:30:47.551 --> 00:30:51.046
that solution, or
that environment you need Boot Camp.

616
00:30:51.046 --> 00:30:53.246
And we didn't talk about
Boot Camp in this episode,

617
00:30:53.246 --> 00:30:56.247
stay tuned though cuz we've got a whole
episode on Boot Camp coming up.

618
00:30:56.247 --> 00:31:01.019
And that's where we actually run the
Windows operating system directly on our

619
00:31:01.019 --> 00:31:02.340
Apple hardware.

620
00:31:02.340 --> 00:31:04.130
And there are some situations
where you need that.

621
00:31:04.130 --> 00:31:06.310
So we are going to take a look at it,
in the next episode.

622
00:31:06.310 --> 00:31:08.520
>> Well that's going to be a lot of fun,
I look forward to that.

623
00:31:08.520 --> 00:31:09.910
Thanks again for stopping by and

624
00:31:09.910 --> 00:31:12.120
explaining these concepts
to our good viewers there.

625
00:31:12.120 --> 00:31:15.340
Hopefully you guys learned a lot out of
this, and you can take that knowledge and

626
00:31:15.340 --> 00:31:16.920
apply it to your environment.

627
00:31:16.920 --> 00:31:19.040
That being said,
we're going to go ahead and sign off.

628
00:31:19.040 --> 00:31:21.470
For IT Pro TV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

629
00:31:21.470 --> 00:31:22.246
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

630
00:31:22.246 --> 00:31:24.193
>> We'll see you next time.

631
00:31:24.193 --> 00:31:31.660
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss the challenges of using Windows applications with Mac hardware. Here they show you how to get around this problem by utilizing the Boot Camp feature of OS X which allows you to install the Windows operating system along side of Mac OS X. They take you from start to finish of preparing, configuring, installing, and post-install features of Boot Camp.
episodes.title: Boot Camp
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.277 --> 00:00:16.916
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.916 --> 00:00:19.432
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.432 --> 00:00:22.580
we're continuing on with our
Mac Integration Basics series.

5
00:00:22.580 --> 00:00:26.749
Joining us back in the studio again
today to lend his very high expertise on

6
00:00:26.749 --> 00:00:27.891
that topic-
>> [LAUGH]

7
00:00:27.891 --> 00:00:30.131
>> It's none other than the man, the myth,

8
00:00:30.131 --> 00:00:31.860
the legend, that is Don Pezet.

9
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:32.980
Don, welcome to the show, sir.

10
00:00:32.980 --> 00:00:35.840
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel,
and you know, I'm excited to jump into

11
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:39.490
what's probably gonna be the weirdest
episode of this entire series because,

12
00:00:39.490 --> 00:00:43.190
all this time we've been talking about
how we can get our Mac to integrate and

13
00:00:43.190 --> 00:00:46.660
play nice with other operating systems and
other devices out there in the network.

14
00:00:46.660 --> 00:00:49.175
In this episode,
we're just gonna say forget it,

15
00:00:49.175 --> 00:00:50.936
let's install Windows on our Mac.

16
00:00:50.936 --> 00:00:52.978
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Thanks for the great hardware.

17
00:00:52.978 --> 00:00:54.499
>> [LAUGH] I know.

18
00:00:54.499 --> 00:00:56.776
So when you buy a Mac,
obviously, it ships with Mac OS.

19
00:00:56.776 --> 00:00:57.765
That's typically what you're running.

20
00:00:57.765 --> 00:01:02.015
This whole exam thing is based on OS X,
that's what we expect to see, but

21
00:01:02.015 --> 00:01:06.547
there are some times where you just need
Windows, where you have to have it for

22
00:01:06.547 --> 00:01:10.400
some particular reason and
it might be a very legitimate reason.

23
00:01:10.400 --> 00:01:13.210
You might have a line of business
application that was specifically

24
00:01:13.210 --> 00:01:16.150
developed for your company that only
runs in Windows and when you run it in

25
00:01:16.150 --> 00:01:20.750
a virtual environment, it doesn't work and
so you can't run it on a Mac.

26
00:01:20.750 --> 00:01:23.300
So does that mean that's it,
you can't have a Mac?

27
00:01:23.300 --> 00:01:25.690
Well, no, you can actually keep your Mac.

28
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:30.100
You can keep running Mac OS, and
you can do what's called dual booting.

29
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:35.830
You can have Mac OS and Windows
running side by side on your hardware.

30
00:01:35.830 --> 00:01:38.050
Now I say side by side,
we can't run both at the same time.

31
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:40.640
If you want both at the same time,
you need virtualization.

32
00:01:40.640 --> 00:01:43.030
In the last episode,
we saw how to use VMware Fusion for

33
00:01:43.030 --> 00:01:45.270
that, then you can run
both at the same time.

34
00:01:45.270 --> 00:01:46.600
It works great.

35
00:01:46.600 --> 00:01:50.520
But if I need it to run
on actual hardware,

36
00:01:50.520 --> 00:01:54.930
if I need Windows to be the base operating
system and it's seeing the RAM and

37
00:01:54.930 --> 00:01:59.950
the CPU and the hard drive and
all that directly, well I got two choices.

38
00:01:59.950 --> 00:02:04.490
Choice number one, I could just format
the hard drive, wipe out Mac OS entirely,

39
00:02:04.490 --> 00:02:07.500
just load Windows on the machine and
off I go.

40
00:02:07.500 --> 00:02:10.440
Now I've got a Windows PC that
just happens to have an Apple

41
00:02:10.440 --> 00:02:13.610
logo stuck on the case, and
I probably paid too much for it.

42
00:02:13.610 --> 00:02:16.103
So, that's option one, right?

43
00:02:16.103 --> 00:02:21.844
Option two though is, hey, I might need
Windows, but not necessarily all the time,

44
00:02:21.844 --> 00:02:26.468
so what if we have them both installed and
when I turn the computer on,

45
00:02:26.468 --> 00:02:30.134
when I push that power button,
how about I get to pick,

46
00:02:30.134 --> 00:02:34.178
do I wanna boot into Windows,
or do I wanna boot into Mac OS?

47
00:02:34.178 --> 00:02:38.150
And if I boot into Mac OS, then OS X comes
up and I get my desktop and everything

48
00:02:38.150 --> 00:02:42.580
works like normal, and then I reboot and
this time when I boot, I pick Windows.

49
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:45.990
And now we boot into Microsoft Windows and
it's running natively on the hardware and

50
00:02:45.990 --> 00:02:49.230
I've got all all of the system
access that we need, all right?

51
00:02:49.230 --> 00:02:52.935
Now from a business standpoint, there's
actually not a whole lot of need for

52
00:02:52.935 --> 00:02:53.680
this, right?

53
00:02:53.680 --> 00:02:57.610
From a business standpoint, usually a line
of business application will run just fine

54
00:02:57.610 --> 00:03:02.160
in a virtual machine, unless it's
expecting some kind of physical

55
00:03:02.160 --> 00:03:05.720
hardware that you can't
have in a virtual machine.

56
00:03:05.720 --> 00:03:07.980
So sometimes there's USB devices for
example,

57
00:03:07.980 --> 00:03:12.280
that can't connect into a virtual machine
or even physical ports in some scenarios.

58
00:03:12.280 --> 00:03:13.690
There might be PCI boards.

59
00:03:13.690 --> 00:03:17.375
You see this on servers all the time where
you need like SSL Accelerator boards or

60
00:03:17.375 --> 00:03:20.570
modem cards or whatever that you
can't attach to a virtual machine.

61
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:23.101
They need to be on a physical machine but
in this show,

62
00:03:23.101 --> 00:03:25.030
we're really talking about desktops.

63
00:03:25.030 --> 00:03:28.821
And on the desktop side, there's really
only one scenario I can think of where

64
00:03:28.821 --> 00:03:31.625
this really comes in handy and
that's video games.

65
00:03:31.625 --> 00:03:33.000
And if you're a big video gamer,

66
00:03:33.000 --> 00:03:35.410
well you can get Macs with
great video cards in them.

67
00:03:35.410 --> 00:03:41.090
At home I've got an iMac, and in my iMac,
it's got an NVIDIA GTX 980 video card,

68
00:03:41.090 --> 00:03:47.190
which is a great video card, but
if I boot into Mac OS, there's not

69
00:03:47.190 --> 00:03:51.570
a whole lot of video games, and the ones
that are there are not very well tuned for

70
00:03:51.570 --> 00:03:55.410
running under Mac, or running under OS X,
so they run pretty crummy.

71
00:03:55.410 --> 00:03:59.270
But if I shut my computer down and
I boot up into Windows,

72
00:03:59.270 --> 00:04:03.260
all of a sudden they run miraculously
great and things run off just fine.

73
00:04:03.260 --> 00:04:04.150
Why is that?

74
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:07.540
Well if you're a developer,
if you're creating a game or

75
00:04:07.540 --> 00:04:10.170
a software application or
whatever, you develop for

76
00:04:10.170 --> 00:04:13.540
the platform that's gonna give
you the biggest install base.

77
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:18.013
And right now in the business world,
Microsoft has

78
00:04:18.013 --> 00:04:22.620
an 85% share of the desktop space
out there in the real world.

79
00:04:22.620 --> 00:04:26.550
That's a huge share, so developers will
usually develop for Windows first.

80
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:29.360
It's even worse in video gaming,
where video games,

81
00:04:29.360 --> 00:04:33.570
Windows is 95% of the computer systems
out there for people playing games and

82
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:37.490
it's just a huge dominated
market there for Windows.

83
00:04:37.490 --> 00:04:40.810
So if you wanna run these applications
to get the best experience,

84
00:04:40.810 --> 00:04:42.160
sometimes there's no substitute for

85
00:04:42.160 --> 00:04:46.650
just booting up into Windows and
fortunately, Apple makes that easy for us.

86
00:04:46.650 --> 00:04:49.450
We don't have to format OS X,
we don't have to get rid of it and

87
00:04:49.450 --> 00:04:52.290
lose it entirely,
you can just have it, and

88
00:04:52.290 --> 00:04:54.740
have Windows sitting there on
the sideline when you need it.

89
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:56.732
And that's exactly what
I do on my iMac at home,

90
00:04:56.732 --> 00:05:00.710
that it's booted into
OS X almost all the time.

91
00:05:00.710 --> 00:05:02.520
Right now, at this very moment,
it's booted into OS X.

92
00:05:02.520 --> 00:05:06.950
And then, I'll go home, I'll work on my
show notes, I'll do other things, all

93
00:05:06.950 --> 00:05:12.490
under Mac OS, and then if I feel the need
to go shoot some aliens in the face or

94
00:05:12.490 --> 00:05:15.750
fly a spaceship or whatever, then I'll
reboot into Windows and I can do that.

95
00:05:15.750 --> 00:05:18.400
And then when I'm done,
I just reboot right back into Mac OS.

96
00:05:18.400 --> 00:05:20.930
So I can now flip between the two.

97
00:05:20.930 --> 00:05:22.010
It's not virtualization.

98
00:05:22.010 --> 00:05:26.730
I'm not running VMware Fusion or
Parallels Desktop or anything like that.

99
00:05:26.730 --> 00:05:29.960
I'm running Apple's Boot Camp technology.

100
00:05:29.960 --> 00:05:34.190
And Boot Camp lets you pick between the
different operating systems when you boot

101
00:05:34.190 --> 00:05:37.910
up, so that you can run both on
the same set of hardware, all right?

102
00:05:37.910 --> 00:05:39.820
Now for most users, this isn't for you.

103
00:05:39.820 --> 00:05:41.190
This isn't something you're gonna need.

104
00:05:41.190 --> 00:05:44.134
But if you fall into one of those
user-case scenarios, and I use video games

105
00:05:44.134 --> 00:05:47.124
cuz that's probably the most common
example, but you may actually have some

106
00:05:47.124 --> 00:05:50.543
kind of business application that needs
this, well, here's your option right here.

107
00:05:50.543 --> 00:05:53.295
And from a business standpoint,
I'll give you a great example.

108
00:05:53.295 --> 00:05:57.086
There's a lot of business software out
there that runs on Windows that you could

109
00:05:57.086 --> 00:06:00.820
run in a virtual environment, but they
have it in their support agreement that

110
00:06:00.820 --> 00:06:03.270
they will not support it
in a virtual environment.

111
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:05.403
They say it's gotta run
an actual hardware.

112
00:06:05.403 --> 00:06:08.780
And [COUGH] the reason they're doing that,
is that if you have a problem and

113
00:06:08.780 --> 00:06:11.690
you call tech support,
they don't wanna have to figure out well,

114
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:14.160
is the problem with the software or
is the problem with virtualization?

115
00:06:14.160 --> 00:06:16.140
So they just tell you, no,
we don't support it on virtualization.

116
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:17.800
You have to run it on actual hardware.

117
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:20.860
And so you'd call and you say well, I'm on
a Mac but I'm running it in VMware Fusion.

118
00:06:20.860 --> 00:06:24.100
And they say oops, can't help you,
thanks, call back later and hang up or

119
00:06:24.100 --> 00:06:24.898
don't call back later.

120
00:06:24.898 --> 00:06:25.880
[LAUGH] Hang up.

121
00:06:25.880 --> 00:06:27.040
So you get that,

122
00:06:27.040 --> 00:06:30.610
and you need to run them on actual
hardware just to be able to get support.

123
00:06:30.610 --> 00:06:33.420
So leveraging Boot Camp lets us do that.

124
00:06:33.420 --> 00:06:37.780
And if you have Boot Camp and something
like VMware Fusion, VMware Fusion does

125
00:06:37.780 --> 00:06:41.800
this cool thing where it will let you boot
up your Boot Camp install as a virtual

126
00:06:41.800 --> 00:06:44.480
machine so you can have it both ways and
that really works out well too.

127
00:06:44.480 --> 00:06:46.810
So there's kind of some neat
technologies out there.

128
00:06:46.810 --> 00:06:50.140
But let's take a look at what's actually
involved in getting this set up.

129
00:06:50.140 --> 00:06:54.490
Now when you buy a Mac, it's gonna have
Mac OS on it and that's it, right?

130
00:06:54.490 --> 00:06:58.195
And so I've got a Mac mini sitting
right here on the desk with me, and

131
00:06:58.195 --> 00:07:01.760
it's running El Capitan,
it's just a base install on it.

132
00:07:01.760 --> 00:07:06.016
I think I installed, this is one, if you
watched our Mac Management Basics show,

133
00:07:06.016 --> 00:07:08.065
we deployed this Mac mini on that show.

134
00:07:08.065 --> 00:07:12.503
So it's got Google Chrome and CyberDoc
installed on it, but otherwise it's

135
00:07:12.503 --> 00:07:17.298
a pretty base install, but it's just
running Mac OS, and that's it, all right?

136
00:07:17.298 --> 00:07:18.624
Let's take a look at the hardrive in this

137
00:07:18.624 --> 00:07:20.270
machine to get an idea of
what I'm talking about.

138
00:07:20.270 --> 00:07:24.920
So here's the Mac mini that I'm on,
and if I fire up

139
00:07:24.920 --> 00:07:29.740
my disk utility, and
take a look at the hard drive, this one's

140
00:07:29.740 --> 00:07:33.910
got a one terabyte hard drive in it
which we'll find here in just a moment.

141
00:07:33.910 --> 00:07:34.620
There we go.

142
00:07:34.620 --> 00:07:39.362
So I can see I've got a one terabyte
hard drive on it, and it's mostly empty.

143
00:07:39.362 --> 00:07:40.931
I don't have anything crazy on here.

144
00:07:40.931 --> 00:07:45.241
So what we're gonna do is we're
gonna install Windows on here, but

145
00:07:45.241 --> 00:07:49.700
my problem that I'm gonna have is
that the hard drive is one terabyte,

146
00:07:49.700 --> 00:07:53.856
it's got a ton of space, but
it's formatted as OS X, or OS 10,

147
00:07:53.856 --> 00:07:58.883
Extended Journaled and that is a great
file system, if you're running a Mac.

148
00:07:58.883 --> 00:08:01.745
But if you're booting to Windows,
Windows doesn't know that file system.

149
00:08:01.745 --> 00:08:02.977
Doesn't make any sense to it.

150
00:08:02.977 --> 00:08:04.860
And so Windows can't read this hard drive.

151
00:08:04.860 --> 00:08:06.900
This hard drive is unusable to Windows.

152
00:08:06.900 --> 00:08:09.210
So, what I'm gonna have
to do is a few things.

153
00:08:09.210 --> 00:08:11.250
I'm gonna have to create
a Windows Installer.

154
00:08:11.250 --> 00:08:15.870
I'm gonna have to create a spot on the
hard drive where Windows can run with its

155
00:08:15.870 --> 00:08:17.580
own file system.

156
00:08:17.580 --> 00:08:20.540
And once all that's done,
I'm gonna have to install Windows.

157
00:08:20.540 --> 00:08:24.941
Now, when you install Mac OS, Apple makes
the hardware that you're running on.

158
00:08:24.941 --> 00:08:28.080
And so Mac OS includes all the drivers for
your hardware,

159
00:08:28.080 --> 00:08:31.010
we never have to worry about drivers
when we're dealing with Macs,

160
00:08:31.010 --> 00:08:33.930
well with the hardware that
it comes with at least.

161
00:08:33.930 --> 00:08:37.403
But on a Windows machine, Microsoft
doesn't know what hardware you're

162
00:08:37.403 --> 00:08:41.043
gonna have, and so they don't have all
the drivers that are built into it, so

163
00:08:41.043 --> 00:08:43.976
when we install Windows it's
gonna be missing some drivers.

164
00:08:43.976 --> 00:08:47.661
And that's the last thing that we have
to do, is we have to give Windows

165
00:08:47.661 --> 00:08:51.594
the additional files that it needs to
support the sound card, and the video

166
00:08:51.594 --> 00:08:55.730
card, and the Bluetooth connectivity,
the network adapter and all of that.

167
00:08:55.730 --> 00:08:58.799
So there's a lot of pieces of this
puzzle that if we go together to create

168
00:08:58.799 --> 00:09:00.400
a bootcamp install.

169
00:09:00.400 --> 00:09:01.460
At the end of the day, it's not so

170
00:09:01.460 --> 00:09:04.360
bad though you'll see we've got a wizard
that guides us through most of this and

171
00:09:04.360 --> 00:09:06.870
we just have to get a few
pieces in the puzzle together.

172
00:09:06.870 --> 00:09:09.060
>> Now, Don,
before we get started into this endeavor,

173
00:09:09.060 --> 00:09:12.510
is there any kind of precautions
that we need to take?

174
00:09:12.510 --> 00:09:16.030
Obviously, we've got a machine that's
working, cost us a little bit of money,

175
00:09:16.030 --> 00:09:20.950
and we're starting to mess with operating
systems and files and hard drives.

176
00:09:20.950 --> 00:09:24.710
So, is there anything we need
to do before we start into this?

177
00:09:24.710 --> 00:09:28.740
So, step number one,
back up your system, right.

178
00:09:28.740 --> 00:09:30.110
When you're messing with the hard drive,

179
00:09:30.110 --> 00:09:32.970
there's always a chance that you could
accidentally erase the hard drive and

180
00:09:32.970 --> 00:09:35.955
if you've got data on there that's
important, well you don't anymore.

181
00:09:35.955 --> 00:09:37.860
[LAUGH] So that would be bad.

182
00:09:37.860 --> 00:09:41.190
Now I'll tell you guys I've worked
with boot camp a ton of times and

183
00:09:41.190 --> 00:09:43.330
I've never once lost data.

184
00:09:43.330 --> 00:09:45.180
But it's definitely possible right?

185
00:09:45.180 --> 00:09:47.380
Because we gotta take this
big terabyte hard drive and

186
00:09:47.380 --> 00:09:51.880
shrink it down to make room for Windows
no we got to stick Windows on there and

187
00:09:51.880 --> 00:09:54.260
there is a moment,
I'll show you when we're setting it up.

188
00:09:54.260 --> 00:09:56.824
There's a moment where if
you made a wrong choice,

189
00:09:56.824 --> 00:10:00.166
you could erase the hard drive that
contains all of your Mac data and

190
00:10:00.166 --> 00:10:03.940
I haven't made that wrong choice yet
but who knows one day it might happen.

191
00:10:03.940 --> 00:10:06.710
I'm in a hurry,
I've taken too much cold medicine, and

192
00:10:06.710 --> 00:10:10.248
I clicked on a wrong drive [LAUGH] and
all of a sudden, I format my machine.

193
00:10:10.248 --> 00:10:12.951
I'm like, no,
I've got Windows, it can boot.

194
